There's a fortune involved that is sizable,
And a fair distribution's advisable.
If the question's decidable—
An answer providable—
Resolution is then realizable.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
Your eau de cologne is the best—
Its attractancy leaves 'em obsessed.
It's especially great
At seducing a mate
When you wear it while scantily dressed.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
You'll find me on pants made of felt.
You'll find me on pants with a welt.
You'll find me on top
Where the pants seem to stop:
I'm a belt loop — a belt for a belt.

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
A camwheel's a wheel with a hump
That makes something move with its thump.
This quite simple notion
Gives to-and-fro motion
To valve-gear or maybe a pump.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My talents were never gymnastic,
As my left foot's deformed; it's dysplastic.
With a custom-made shoe
I can walk good as you,
But do backflips? The strain would be drastic.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
The committee that formed in September
Has co-opted me: I'm a new member.
We all hold different roles,
Serve the club (Indoor Bowls).
It's hard work. I'll have quit by December.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
He's a cuculine conman, a pest —
A parasite, pleasingly dressed.
Do not fall for the lies,
Or his needful disguise,
Or he'll — cuckoo-like — conquer your nest.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I resolved my old image I'd scotch
With a makeover, carve a new notch.
So silk Y-fronts I wore
But I got rather sore:
The elastic was chafing my crotch.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
Surprised? I just stood there and blabbered.
"Well, pickle my walnuts!" I jabbered.
When head-honcho Len
Marked my waltz as a ten,
Well my gast was incredibly flabbered.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Creative destruction's mutation
That accompanies marked innovation.
Something new comes along,
And old firms, not so strong,
Must improve or else face liquidation.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
"There's more on the next page. Just read."
"Court's adjourned. After lunch we'll proceed."
If c-o-n-t-d
Is the word that you see,
It's continued. See where it will lead.

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
Where's the medical aid for our troops?
When they're injured, they're treated like dupes.
Those who've lost arm or leg
Need our help, yet must beg
Us for care, forced to hurtle through hoops.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
My wife says I'm constantly tweaking,
Fixing windows or pipes that are leaking.
But why all the hassle?
A man's home is his castle—
That is, in a manor of speaking.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
I accomplish a lot every day.
There are biscuits for breakfast (hooray!),
Then what treats I can beg,
Like a piece of Mom's egg.
If I don't get my way, I just bay.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
On a map, you may see this: N. Z.
That's where Airedale producers will be.
Semi-soft, you will note,
With a deep-red wax coat.
This fine cheese is no dog, you'll agree.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The chronically tardy Maria
Was late for her flight to Korea.
For each date, she'll be late.
Show up early? You'll wait.
Never prompt—well, you get the idea.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
On the old Woodrow Wilson Bridge rubble
Shipped down to Point Lookout, a bubble
Of oyster spat hulches;
This reef-to-be culch is
Recycling that's well worth the trouble.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Acid sulfite, just what could it be?
It's an anion, HSO3-.
You'd create quite a few
If you mixed SO2
With hydroxide. Seems basic to me.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
I'm so pleased with my ermine fur coat,
Snowy white and as soft as a stoat.
The detachable hood,
When removed, really could
Make a hat for my kid — pretty goat!

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
"You blame me for your sins? Makes me sick!
And you think I get some kind of kick
Out of toasting lost souls
Over freshly fanned coals?
I've been demonised," grumbles Old Nick.

limerick_list.author: hugh.adler
limerick_list.text:
A man who writes limericks?  That's him.
He indulges each day in that whim.
This man is no stranger
To peril and danger—
He spends his time out on a lim.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
When I tote up the women I've had,
I start with my wife, then I add . . .
Um, no other, my dear.
There's just you, and it's clear
That my aggregate's ONE. And I'm glad.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
The villainess surnamed de Vil
Wanted furs, and she maybe does still.
She was far past desire;
She was ardent, on fire.
Doramania drove her to kill.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
"My egestion production," said Phil,
"Is near zero since eating Lil's swill.
Doc, it's been several weeks
Since I've parted both cheeks."
Doc said, "Yes, a packed bowel's no thrill."

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
The crapshooter cried, "I can't lose,
Come on, babe needs a new pair of shoes!"
But his luck and shrill talkin'
Left baby still walkin'
Around with bare feet and the blues.

limerick_list.author: man from tashkent
limerick_list.text:
A person from northwestern France
(Of Celtic extraction, by chance)
Once was known as Armoric.
A fact most historic.
They probably wore funny pants.

limerick_list.author: Harris Risman
limerick_list.text:
I'm a certified nut. I am ravin'—
Rantin', ravin'. A certified maven
(That means "expert" to you)
From a mental health crew
Probes the reasons why I'm misbehavin'.

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
When Anne mentioned this site, my librarian
Replied: "Sign me up, my name's Marion."
Then I thought to myself:
"Hmm, these girls of the shelf
May descend on us. Better be wary, Anne."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Ms Minnelli, I loved Cabaret!
You were excellent!  So was Joel Grey.
Win the Oscar (your due)
And then I predict you
Will see blockbuster roles come your way.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
If someone jumps out and shouts "Boo!",
Crinogenic responses are due:
Epinephrine's released,
Which brings out your beast,
And you beat the poor guy black and blue.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My cat is an old Siamese
Who's as free as the birds in the trees.
Her favorite lair
Is my overstuffed chair
Where she's comfortable, safe, and at ease.

limerick_list.author: Jean McEwen
limerick_list.text:
Eating broccoli, cabbage, and kale
Makes folks smile when they step on the scale.
These crucifers, chock
Full of nutrients, rock!
They form gas, but they'll help you stay hale.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
When competitors act in unition,
The word for it's coopetition.
That means rivals will "sleep
Together" to reap
Joint rewards, bringing deals to fruition.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
So-called gooseberries near Coromandel,
The tart star fruit is tricky to handle.
For with Lipitor's use,
The carambola's juice
Can extinguish your heart like a candle.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
"To rate work that your muscles will do,
There's an ergograph wired up to you."
It measured each action,
Each little contraction,
As I huffed and I puffed and I blew.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
With efforts concerted, they tried
To defeat the bad bill—sweep aside
The majority's vote—
And, together, to float
An amendment, thus turning the tide.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
Dry vermouth: take white wine and infuse
With aromas of herbs. Divine booze!
Mix it well with chilled gin,
Pour and drink (it's no sin)
Any time, any place that you choose.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
To concamerate means "to arch over,"
Like my stride as I walk across clover,
Or the rainbow I see
Curving over the lea
In my carefree career as a rover.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"This computer I have is a pip.
It decrypts with a fast clipper chip,"
Said my son who's a nerd.
Answered Gramps, who'd mis-heard,
"It's a trip on the last clipper ship?"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Re your invoice for teaching the dactyl:
The bill, though well totaled, in fact'll
Stay unpaid. It's a crime
That you've wasted my time.
I had asked you to teach me the fractal.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
Don't like sweating? You might try agaric,
A mushroom.  But summon a cleric,
For if it's not right,
Your demise will be quite
An unpleasant one, harsh and barbaric.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My son-in-law Wayne is insane
About fashion; he's terribly vain.
All his tailor-made suits
(And they really are beauts)
Are of worsted—the finest delaine.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I'm Elvis's number one fan.
I had every recording the man
Ever made. Now I find
Graceland's vault has been mined
Once again, a perpetual plan.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Wait a moment. I've got a suspicion
That this volume's a true first edition
Of Tartuffe, worth a mint—
The play's first time in print.
What a find! It's my lifetime ambition.

limerick_list.author: Peter Meyer
limerick_list.text:
At Emmental (Swiss, if you please)
They are known for a fine type of cheese
That won't go down like silk,
Though its basis is milk—
Full of holes, it is sure to appease.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
It's not funny, this money we lend
To Greece, so that she can pretend
To pay off her debt.
It's mysterious, yet
She continues to think we're her friend.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
This guy's boom car's a pain in the butt!
He is not just some audio nut—
At one-fifty db's
I said, "Turn it down, please!
It's a hazard, you know."  He said, "WHAT?!"

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
One thing camels and lions may share?
It's the light sandy-brown of their hair.
Known as fallow, this hue
Helps to hide them from view —
And cleans up well with minimum care.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
In cricket, white lines are called creases,
Dividing the pitch into pieces.
There's the bowling, the popping,
The batting… I'm stopping!
The supply of crease words never ceases.

limerick_list.author: Kalleh
Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
Take some bones, add fresh herbs wrapped in cloth,
Set to simmer, then skim off the froth.
Add some carrots, tomatoes,
Leeks, parsley, potatoes,
Cook an hour, then strain off the broth.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano and Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
EBay, Best Buy and Amazon? Pissed!
Online service these e-tailers missed.
Many surfers now turn
To a place where they learn
Much from Angie's smart word-of-mouth List.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Broken-boned in his auto's impaction,
Mick's abed, wholly bored from inaction.
Since his nurses can't let no
Young chicks in, he'll get no
Distraction from boredom in traction.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Ciceronianisms abound
In Phil's speech; these he feels are profound;
And although I'm aware
That it's mostly hot air,
There's a nice oratorical sound.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Though, of course, I have talents galore,
People tend to attribute yet more,
So they think I could be
Poet Laureate — me! —
When my rhymes are exceedingly weak.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
In an automat (self-serve café),
Much cuisine can be seen on display.
Make your choice, then guess what?
Drop your coin down the slot.
There's your chow!  Eat it now! On your way!

limerick_list.author: Taillefer
limerick_list.text:
An eleve (pupil or learner)
May not be a genius like Turner.
For example, at school,
I liked acting the fool—
Joked around, but of work was a spurner.

limerick_list.author: Engineer
limerick_list.text:
If a governor worthy of praise
(In Algiers in its Ottoman phase)
Was the greatest of all,
Then I guess you could call
This fine leader the best of all deys.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
And then 4GL gives you more jets,
For you work with collections and sets.
New reports every day:
With statistics you play,
As you trawl through your data with nets.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
A cross-eyed old woman named Rose
Seems to stare at the end of her nose.
With this ocular trouble,
She always sees double,
So she calls her poor husband "the Joes."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Reading Seuss to my son through the month
Brings ingenious lexical funth.
How amazing these times
And astounding the rhymes!
I suggest that you try it—just oneth!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A fashion-monger, Poppa's a fop.
In his wardrobe, he's over-the-top.
To be fully in fashion
Is our dandy-dad's passion.
We call him our "popinjay pop."

limerick_list.author: Britunculus
limerick_list.text:
Existentialist gardien de but,
The novelist Albert Camus
Mused "to do is to be"
Whilst his team, down nil-three,
Was protesting "to be is to do".

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
If it escalates just a bit more,
Your squabble could grow to a war.
Cut the nasty invective
And find some perspective.
There are worse things than socks on the floor.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
We've for doubtfulness quite a variety
Of choices to use with propriety.
With a bit of pomposity,
We can choose dubiosity,
But my preference is simply dubiety.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Epidermal cells, healthy, abide
In a layer attached side-by-side.
After keratinolysis
Yields acantholysis,
Gaps between cells become wide.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Are you comfy—at home and relaxed?
And your workload—not stressed, overtaxed?
Love to keep you around,
And we're sure you'll rebound,
But we've found you, well, shiftless. You're axed.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
Since we can't start our campfire with that wood
(It's too damp),  I'll go get us some fatwood.
It's a resinous pine
That will light up just fine.
What I'm doing's what any smart cat would.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
All romance my sweet William eschews
When he woos me with pizza and booze.
Though he's wantin', I won't,
Cuz, you see, Billy don't
Ever send me those sweet billets-doux.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A mothering brisling declared
To a little one, "Don't get ensnared
In the net by the pier."
But the brit didn't hear
For it seems he was herring-impaired.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
A suburb of Plymouth, UK,
Is called Devonport. There an array
Of a few of the best
UK warships, at rest,
Await orders to get under way.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
You made trouble; I think that's a shame.
It's your fault—that's what people will claim.
But your nonchalant style
And your Cheshire cat  smile
Means you've someone in mind you can blame.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Tussilago farfara's gold flowers
Appear before leaves in green bowers
Of spring… and don't scoff,
As this plant helps a cough—
Little coltsfoot has strong herbal powers.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
"This case", said the judge, "is complex:
The defendant, a dwarf, shot his ex.
Set him free, though, I rule."
The D.A. kept his cool,
Since de minimis non curat lex.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Fifty miles, that's about eighty clicks—
We'd hiked eighty hot clicks through the sticks.
What the hell could we say?
The old man led the way.
He's the terror and pride of Fort Dix.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Disagreement: our lack of accord
Means you fight us; you're never on board
With majority rule.
Though you may think it cruel,
We'll expel you till order's restored.

limerick_list.author: John Wellington Wells
limerick_list.text:
Was he showing his strong moral fiber
By taking the bribe from the briber?
He wrote on the bill,
Which he placed on the Hill,
The words "Congressman Smith" then "(Transcriber)."

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
A brotherhood might be a clan
Or some workers united in plan.
But such unions are small;
If I use it at all,
It's the brotherhood, simply, of man.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A man who's a dotard (a dotant)
Has a wit that is no longer potent,
But he's not without charms—
Like an old coat of arms
With a dotty gray goose that is flotant.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Ol' man Quinn domiciliates cats,
Giving housing to hundreds. (He's bats!)
He's been mocked and maligned
And arrested and fined
And evicted from seventeen flats.

limerick_list.author: Shelby Forrest
limerick_list.text:
The old codger was grouchy and crass,
Like a blanket of blight on the grass.
His picture was sketched
On a window and etched.
He was seen as a "pane in the glass."

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
First I'll muddle some sugar with lime,
Adding ice and cachaça, then I'm
Serving each Carioca
Just one drink: no joke.  A
Caipirinha, they'll think, is sublime.

limerick_list.author: MattMonitto
limerick_list.text:
The newborn colt's life had just started
When the stable boss, cruel and coldhearted,
Turned the mare into glue.
It's a tale we all rue:
Just a foal and his mommy soon parted.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
If you purchase coal tar, you're a buyer.
If you say it smells nice, you're a liar.
From its anthracene goo
Comes alizarin's hue.
If you know about that, you're a dyer.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
I pen paeans of praise, oh so lyrical,
Frothy pink clouds panegyrical.
Here is my foamiest—
"Hail the Encomiast:
Ode to Myself (Mother's Miracle)".

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
It is good for a bride to be slim
And compact in her body and limb,
For a cumbrous physique
May inhibit technique —
Or diminish one's vigor and vim.

limerick_list.author: Seth Brown and Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
ADHD means you've a proclivity
For disorders of hyperactivity.
Your attention will race
Just all over the place.
There's a deficit of productivity.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Delineatory strokes are a start
And an outline, a frame, for my art.
Unfulfilled, though, they're static,
So monochromatic—
Insipid—mere skin with no heart.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The Austrian Adolf F. Brix
Was a master of chemistry tricks.
His hydrometer scale
Gives us measured detail—
How much sugar there is in this mix.

limerick_list.author: nevadaace
limerick_list.text:
You're in France, all your crops are a-growin'.
It's summer, your goat's milk is flowin'.
Now, don't make a mistake—
Use that raw milk to make
Banon cheese, and with pride you'll be glowin'.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
If a pressure group tries forcing through
Some pet project abhorrent to you,
Checks and balances make
The proposing group take
Up a much more considerate view.

limerick_list.author: David Franks
limerick_list.text:
Formed concrete, first used as a frame
Or as fill, for the moderns became
A new toy to expose,
And now everyone knows
Brutalism. Corbu gets the blame.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
To the east, there's the foundland that's New.
Further west there is Brunswick, New too.
Nova Scotia's not my land,
Nor is Prince Edward Island,
Nor "and Labrador." (Did it! Woo-Hoo!!)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Walk through burweed that grows between rocks;
You'll acquire a memento that shocks.
Little fruits full of stickers
Will stick to your knickers,
And cling to the tops of your socks.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"A double ax? Golly, what is it?"
"It's in artwork (Minoan) exquisite.
In real life, here's the facts:
It's a double-edged ax
Found in neighborhoods I'd never visit."

limerick_list.author: VERaLOE
limerick_list.text:
"Your first line in this lim is no thriller,
'Cause your pillar is only a filler.
Words that just take up space
Are a total disgrace!"
Man, this WE is a killer!

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
While St. Mark and the Doges held sway,
Jealous French called Crete's hub La Canée.
La Canea? Venetian,
Til the Turkish accretion,
And the Greeks call Chaniá theirs today.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
What three films won best picture awards
And were movies, without guns or swords,
That each featured a sport?
Plus I'm glad to report
That the public attended in hordes.

limerick_list.author: Kirk Zurell
limerick_list.text:
Outside, in a bush, there's a birdie.
At night, when I sleep, he gets wordy.
I'll catch him to thank him,
And bolt on a crank-him,
And fashion a new hurdy-gurdy.

limerick_list.author: Nick Szymanski
limerick_list.text:
If you want a description of air,
I shall give you not one, but a pair:
Song, in operas sung,
And the food for your lung
That's unseen, omnipresent and rare.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
A young thespian living in Bisbee
Grew bored playing ultimate Frisbee.
"I'm feeling malaise—
What this town needs are plays,
So when will the tour of Les Mis be?"

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
My threshold for boredom is low.
If a speech is long-winded or slow
It may spark a response
That not everyone wants,
Namely, fill me with get-up-and-go.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
As he gazed at the guns 'cross the bay,
The commander was last heard to say:
"Sure, those bastards are game,
But they've got lousy aim.
Couldn't hit a barn door at this ra— "

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
Now I wait in my death cell. I sit.
Soon I'll walk the "last mile". This is it.
On the gurney I'll lie,
Strapped down tight till I die.
And tomorrow you'll see my obit.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Miss Edna Saint Vincent Millay
Is quoted from Nome to Taipei.
Her candle was splendid:
It burned, double-ended,
And turned one last night into day.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A tornado in town represents
An unfortunate turn of events.
Newly homeless: "We're sad.
Under canvas, life's bad!"
(How ironic that term means "intense.")

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
The process of colorization
By computer soon brought on elation.
And with black-and-white prints
Thus enhanced, I'm convinced
Classic films create new conversation.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Though municipal means are quite meagre,
For advice our electees are eager.
To this end, large amounts'll
Be spent by the council
On fact-finding trips to Antigua.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I'd a hammer, but nothing to bang,
Till I found an old picture to hang,
But I did something dumb—
Went and hammered my thumb.
Up I sprang, and yelled, "Dang!" (Yup, that's slang.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Cut my booze?" cried the gin-soaked ol' coot.
"Save the water for bathin' in. Shoot,
If a liquor, I think,
Is befittin' to drink,
Then, by God, it's too good to dilute!"

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
See this false smut of rice? Farmer's bane —
It reduces the weight of each grain.
Seems this smut isn't "true".
(As to why, the main clue
Is its pathogen's phylum, that's plain.)

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
On safari, e.g. in the Congo,
One may often encounter a bongo,
And although there are some
Who suppose it's a drum,
It's an antelope (striped), so they're wrongo.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
Though you're fat, if you're rich then some lass'll
Say "Yes" just to live in your castle.
Don't try losing weight;
You'll be blessed with a mate
If your cash'll grow fast as your ass'll.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A canner's a woman or man
Who can seal or make airtight a can,
Give a slip that is pink
To a worker, or sink
A three-pointer to shut up a fan.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Sweat droppeth al doune Adam's cheer,
Eke his breste & his bac. He pays dere
For that appel he ate:
For his rest hee must wait
Until brethles & cold on his bier.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
"These uniform Pringles are crinkled,
With a crispature evenly wrinkled.
Since they're salty as hell,
I gulp soda as well—
By the gallon," said Tim as he tinkled.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Found a list of kings' tombs in this jar.
It's in code, so we can't go too far
Till we break down the text.
So that's what we'll do next —
Cryptographically learn where they are.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
"The crazies," remarked John McCain,
"Are supporting The Donald — insane!
The man's egocentricity
And love of publicity
Rational people disdain."

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
A security leak quickly reaches
The chief of detectives, who screeches,
"Get cracking, my corps.
Get advice — find a whore.
Get an expert in zipping up breaches."

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
Jolly chippies were awesome to hear
In the '80s, when hard discs were dear.
Floppy discs couldn't hack
Pre-made sounds to play back;
Real-time chiptunes are gone though, I fear.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
David Akeman played banjo with ease
And told jokes, making Hee Haw a breeze.
Known as String Bean, this lean,
Tall performer was seen
In long night shirt and jeans to his knees.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Cincinnatus was U.S. Grant's horse
And was at Appomattox, of course.
Since Lee's Traveler balked,
The two steeds never talked,
But Lee's gelding showed zero remorse.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In a combat zone (theater of war)
You'll find many a crack army corps,
While back home it's a prime
Urban district for crime—
Drive-by shootings, narcotics, and more.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan M. Guberman
limerick_list.text:
In your babehood your life was so mild.
You were innocent, still just a child.
But you're now a young man,
So a girl's babehood can
(And assuredly will) drive you wild.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
We were sitting around getting stoned,
When Sheila (my dealer's ex) phoned:
"There's a raid. Got a text.
Says they'll come for you next."
Which they did.  And that's how I got boned.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
A term of endearment pops out
Of my mouth and my heart. It's about
A dear puppy's sweet kiss
That prompts my near bliss
And elicits an "aw" for "Wet Snout".

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
Whenever my relatives come,
I bake a big cake filled with rum.
Though they always complain,
It at least kills the pain,
So I fight them for every last crumb.

limerick_list.author: Scott Campisi
limerick_list.text:
In the course of a speech you digress
And, reflecting, directly address
A conceptual thing
Like "O Death, where's your sting?"
Your apostrophe shows your finesse.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
King Arthur encountered a fellow
Who was known for his backbone of Jell-O
And lack of acumen.
"I dub thee Sir Rumen—
Like earwax, you're thick and you're yellow."

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
The firemen faced some great harm there,
Responding to some guy's alarm blare.
The reason? No joking,
He fell asleep smoking,
While sitting, relaxed, in an armchair.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
My asparagus bed may be gone,
Since the hailstorm rained ice chunks upon
All its pretty green shoots.
Yet I hope from the roots
To see violet-tipped spears  near my lawn.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Will angels go forth on the Earth
To herald the forthcoming birth
With the blast of a horn
When that litter is born?
Do you know what those puppies are worth?

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
First pictures and trinkets and plaster,
Then masonry, faster and faster,
Shook madly and tumbled,
As everything rumbled
In Christchurch's second disaster.

limerick_list.author: proof
turnip
limerick_list.text:
By the ole Mississip' and Ohio,
A single white flower — oh my, oh!
"T. nivale," writes William,
"Dwarf white (or snow) trillium,
That's the whole dwarf white wakerobin  bio."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
An achievement holds more than one's shield.
Our particulars here are revealed,
For the helm shows our rank,
These beasts, whom we thank —
You may guess why the sea forms our field.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
If your doc's diagnosis has shown
Toward adrenal shortcoming you're prone,
You had better get cracking—
Aldosterone's lacking!
Take deoxycorticosterone.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
Though she said I was boorish and crass,
That Grace is a merciful lass.
To ensure it was total,
Her put-down was scrotal:
A knee in the groin! Coup de grâce!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
My chemistry lab partner Marge
Claims this cation's sure to loom large
On our midterm reports.
It's a counter, of sorts,
To an ion of opposite charge.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Mother Nature is someone from whom
Folks at times get a message of gloom,
Like the parents, forlorn,
Of a girl-child who's born
With ametria—lacking a womb.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
"What's he saying? I can't understand a
Buffoon who says 'Let's 'ave a gander!'
I mean ... what the deuce?
Does he want a male goose?"
"No, a look  — at your pet salamander!"

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Disagreer's sharp pricking critique
Dissed Ms Betty's The Fem'nine Mystique.
Read from Melbourne to Munich,
Ms G's Female Eunuch:
Germane to misogynist clique.

limerick_list.author: mino
limerick_list.text:
The word ace, for a pilot, conveys
He's made forty-two kills on soirées.
Wait: soirées? I meant sorties;
And not in the forties,
But five. Oy, it's one of those days.

limerick_list.author: woodfostersmith
limerick_list.text:
From its lawns filled with plastic flamingos
To its restaurant, "Three Drunken Gringos,"
This southwestern town
Has a tacky renown,
And its motto is apt: "Anything Goes."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Here it says genus Ductor is linked
To the jackfish. My book is succinct,
And it says to observe
One that's swimming with verve
Is unlikely—the fish is extinct.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Coruscatingly witty, he shines;
On each topic he brightly opines.
He's so dazzlingly smart
That he's captured my heart...
(I've had nine of these blackberry wines.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The river the Swiss call the Aar
Will meander, but never get far
From the canton of Bern,
Whose inhabitants learn
All its turns as they cross it by car.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"And the winner is... HILARY SWANK!"
"Me? I'm trailer park trash. Gotta thank
Every co-nominee.
You're all better than me."
False modesty, Hil. Let's be frank.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
So my big chance has come and I know it.
I've the talent and now I must show it.
I must try my best
For this is the test.
(Oh, my God! I just know that I'll blow  it!)

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Our abilities help us succeed,
But we're ruled by a Communist creed;
The more money we make,
The more money they take
And distribute according to need.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Mix of lowland and mountain terrain,
It obtained independence from Spain.
Rich in culture and ore,
Yes, Colombia's more
Than just criminals selling cocaine.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It's the set of assumptions I make
That support the position I take—
The foundation I'm laying,
My basis for saying,
"Hey, buddy, go jump in a lake!"

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
Said the clown: Is it bringing you down
That you can't, from this fence, see the town?
You don't need to be tall
To see over this wall;
Yes, this ha-ha will soon lift your frown.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I feel good when my books show black ink,
Meaning profit—a boon, I would think—
As with losses come red
Ink that shows up instead.
I see red, and I'm not tickled pink.

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
On Twitter, he'd woo and he'd ply 'er
With promises — things he would buy 'er.
But now that they've met,
She's beset with regret.
He's a fabulist: Big fat old liar!

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
Her dress was a long, flowing number,
Not at all the right choice for a rumba,
But the crowd cheered with glee
When she tore the skirt free—
The better her legs to discumber.

limerick_list.author: GAD
limerick_list.text:
A fluorochrome's that which fluoresces,
To mark biological messes.
To say any more
As to what they're used for,
Your guess is as good as my guess is.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
Watch a typesetter setting some type,
And observe this occasional gripe:
"They're distinct, these marks are:
One's the split ¦,
While the other, in fact, is the |."

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
Find a needle in there? Well you may;
But it could take a year and a day—
So much grass, cut and dried,
Piled up fodder. We tried,
But a haystack's a big stack of hay!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The loggers are brushing the road,
Filling holes so the work won't be slowed.
It's a difficult pass
Through a swampy morass
For a skidder that's dragging a load.

limerick_list.author: Miss Mimi
limerick_list.text:
Barack, people say they respect you,
And they might cast their votes to elect you.
While that may be the truth,
Once alone in the booth,
The voters could Bradley effect you.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Newly loosed from his mom's apron strings,
He's a fledgling; he's trying his wings.
And though dazed or distressed
(So much world to digest),
He's entranced by what each morning brings.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
I despise conjunctivas chemotic.
My left eye appears quite exotic —
Like a lychee. The right
Looks much more of a fright,
So I'm seeking an antibiotic.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Two cups cycasin, one diced-up lime,
One cup flour (self-rising is prime)—
Beat with whisk until fluffy,
Then bake until puffy.
Serves four and kills three over time.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
John Audubon, chronicled birder,
Authored bird books, an honored bird-worder.
Myriad species he painted;
His technique, though, seems tainted,
His specimens gleaned by bird-murder.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I feel I should call her "Your Highness."
Her divineness is more than just fineness.
She's the top of the line,
And I pray she'll be mine.
(After mineness, I hope for supineness.)

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
You're expert.  You're skillful.  OK.
You're master of all you survey.
In this country I guess
You'd be called a success.
In France, they would say you're au fait.

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
You stand out in a crowd—that's for sure.
(Are you certain that outfit's couture?)
Your conspicuous clothes
Really hide that botched nose...
But your fashion disease?—There's no cure.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The philosophy?  Somewhat absurd.
Many photos (mere padding?) were blurred.
There's no question, however,
The author was clever.
Richard Bach made a buck on a bird.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
O, One!  Upon thee I've bestowed,
As my Macintosh hastens to load,
(And as well upon Zero,
My alternate hero)
An ode to your binary code.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A trailer park torn all asunder
By a storm left the people to wonder.
The power of lightning?
It sure can be frightening!
Still, no one gets hurt by the thunder.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
She perched, without pants, on my blotter;
I imagined the scene would get hotter.
It was not what you think:
She had sat in some ink,
And was hoping the pad would de-spot her.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The butt hinges flush with the jamb
Can be stressed and come loose with a slam.
I was whacked in the butt
By the door I just shut,
Which appeared to be muttering, "Scram!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"The drunk tank's where boozers are jailed,
So how long till the fat cell's unveiled?"
That's my heavy friend, Jeff.
"If DWF
Becomes outlawed, I'll surely be nailed!"

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
They complained of a man from Connecticut
That every acquaintance he met, he cut.
'Twas not New England pride,
The poor guy was cross-eyed;
Just poor vision, not flouting of etiquette.

limerick_list.author: DBRHoffman
limerick_list.text:
A pricklesome plant is the cactus,
And, no matter how one might attract us,
It takes muscle control
To swallow one whole,
And probably decades of practice.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
You seem innocent, prim and controlled;
For a rascal, you're playing it cold.
So I always have felt
As if butter won't melt
In your mouth.  Well, your act's getting old.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
It's Alzheimer's Day at the dance,
And two oldsters say, "Give it a chance!"
In they walk, arm-in-arm,
With spectacular charm,
But not cognizant neither wears pants.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
An event makes you go back in time
And, whilst there, what you do is the prime
Starting link in a chain
That will loop round again
To the point where you go back in time...

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
With a digital watch there's no chance
Of mistaking the time.  A quick glance
At the numbers' display
Means there's clearly no way
You'll be late for your date at the dance.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
Aren't you catching my drift? Please desist!
Don't tell me you've not got the gist
Of requests, though polite,
Meaning: "Stop! Behave right!"
If that's so, I'll explain with my fist.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
"Listen closely. Keep up at the back!
Do you understand so far, young Jack?"
"I can't follow too well
What you're saying, please tell
Me more slowly. I'll soon be on track."

limerick_list.author: Goldie
Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
To a fire he was surely no stranger,
Not Granger, the bold forest ranger.
At one sign of a spark,
He'd warn Yellowstone Park
Of a clear and severe present danger.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
They're rafters, a pair, that provide
Extra strength 'cause they're yoked side by side.
So a couple-close roof
Won't collapse, giving proof
That, in building, you're fit to be tied.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Does El Toro attack seeing red?
That's the myth that we've always been fed.
What's the story in full?
Can't ken red. Tale's just bull.
He is color blind. Soon he'll be dead.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Comprehensive, it caters for all:
Has both brain-box and thickie in thrall,
In theory, to school,
Though, in practice, the fool
Pulls down others, who go to the wall.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When our ancestors felt the vibration
Of the earth—its abrupt agitation—
Cavemen cringed and were scared;
They were never prepared
For an earthquake—the ground's concussation.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Faith has seven fine kids she holds dear.
Pam has eight (and all monsters, I hear).
Babs and May, I'm aware,
Both have nine and so they're
Grand multiparas all, that is clear.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
My antique, rather costly brass cornet
Has valves, and engravings adorn it.
Do cornopeans, though,
Pay the landlady? No.
So, blow it, I might as well pawn it.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My problems I long to unload:
The critics' opinions erode
My self-confidence, eat at
My pride. My defeat at
Their hands makes me want to explode.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Cotoneaster — I love its bright berry:
So small, but as red as a cherry.
What is more, blackbirds need
It, in winter, to feed —
Or, at least, it will make their days merry.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
Said the oak to the elm, "It is true.
It was love at first sight, and I knew
When we wed in our wild
I would bear you a child,
And I just named it Elmen for you."

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
The extent of the quake, I'll surmise,
Means the death toll continues to rise.
They cleared bodies and rubble;
Disease now makes trouble
Where poor sanitation applies.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Called to Horeb, Elijah knew fear.
In what form would the Lord God appear?
He felt earth, wind and fire.
His alarm grew much higher.
"Turn your iPod off, prophet—I'm here."

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I'm a rough kind of guy with an edge,
Whose abruptness some people allege
Is perhaps rather sharp
(A familiar carp),
So I'll chamfer it now. That's my pledge.

limerick_list.author: BobHale and Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Your 'do might be something to dig
Or mistaken by bros for a wig,
But if ever the door
Isn't wide enough for
Your hair, then your 'fro is too big.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Though your offering rings a bit strange,
We're still flexible, subject to change.
Though both ailing and faded,
We might be persuaded
To spring for a home on the range.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
That skunk! He came on like a rose,
But he's stuck on himself, and it shows.
He grows less and less saintly,
That fake halo glows faintly.
I propose we depose him. He goes!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
What I lack for this piece is a crook.
It's not there, though I took a good look.
I can't alter the pitch
Of my horn. What a bitch.
(Seems I grabbed the wrong bag — I mis-took.)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
I am Hansel-and-Gretel-inclined,
Leaving traces of breadcrumbs behind.
Then that flock—first it comes,
Then it gobbles my crumbs.
Where's that chumetz I'm trying to find?

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
A masochist woman, named Flo,
Married up with a sadist, called Joe.
Flo begged, "Darling, mistreat me,
Please whip me and beat me!"
But Joe, smiling coldly, said, "No."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
A cockchafer asked me, "What say
I destroy vegetation today?"
"You damn beetle!" I cried.
"In my fields you reside.
I've no choice but get rubbed the wrong way!"

limerick_list.author: Egbert
limerick_list.text:
Administratively bereft
Lay India's Punjab, now cleft.
But soon — goodness gracious! —
Chandigarh (modern, spacious)
Rose anew for the bit that was left.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Just before he was ready to duel,
One combatant, afraid, lost his cool.
Someone beckoned his second
"He'll stand in," it was reckoned.
He demurred, "Do I look like a fool?"

limerick_list.author: Fleur De Lim
limerick_list.text:
Words won't flow if you've got writer's block.
Blocked-up veins give your ticker a knock.
There's a Blockbuster store
Up the block—fun galore—
Unblocks stress knots as hard as a rock.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
That devotionist talks the whole day
To the Lord, in his God-fearing way.
His fervor's impressive;
In fact, it's excessive —
The guy is no work and all pray.

limerick_list.author: kandabongo
limerick_list.text:
All my nerves are exploding, it's true!
And they're blowing their cellular goo!
This loss axoplasmic
Is truly orgasmic—
You sure are one hell of a view!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If you paint your ass purple, that's funky!
Make its hair a red Mohawk? That's punky.
But don't do it, I say.
Leave the animal grey
Because colorlessness flatters a donkey.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
The sails set on a yawl, fore and aft,
Are the mizzen and main on this craft,
Both aligned with her keel.
It's a rig with a real
Graceful look, deep or shallow her draught.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Cuddly comfort dogs soothe Donald's stress
Like that caused by a ravaging press.
Not a stray from Sri Lanka
But two-headed JarVanka
Consoles when the Prez makes a mess.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
To a twig, misdirection was sent:
It was changed in its course or intent;
Like the numeral 8,
It grew crooked, not straight.
Now you notice a tree has been bent.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Total cloudlessness reigns in a sky
Clear and black, with the moon riding high.
Winter stars before dawn
Glitter brightly. They're gone,
As the sun applies tender blue dye.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A madeleine broken in pieces
And dipped in a teacup releases
Remembrances of
Temps perdu and a love.
So we learn from a Proust anamnesis.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
The chorus was meant to be choralizing,
But altos and tenors were quarrelizing.
Sopranos and basses
Abandoned their places…
The soloists found it demoralizing.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
My : is spastic, no fun,
& my .'s late, I'm undone.
Should I # in frustration
@ life's punctuation,
/ my wrists, or go ! with a gun?

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
To debilitate Drew I made stew
That I poisoned by adding some yew.
A devitalized spouse
Gave us run of the house;
Then his wife and I did what we do.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
The word's dicarboxylic?! We knew
That it means that a compound has two
Carboxylate groups.
Though you jumped through some hoops,
Your charade clues were not coming through!

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
For canals is old Venice renowned,
And in Birmingham some can be found.
Painted ladies of night
Think both cities a fright,
Since the streetwalkers there might get drowned.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Democracy often is spurned
By some activist judges, concerned
We're a nation of fools
Where majority rules.
Thus, our will is, at will, overturned.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Don't scuttle from this derivation,
Or smoulder in deep concentration.
Fallen trees compressed tight
Through the aeons' long night
Put the coal into coalification.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The emcee is obese—roly-poly—
And he answers his phone wholly drolly:
"No, it's not Monty Hall
Who has picked up your call.
Holy Moly, it's jolly Joe Foley!"

limerick_list.author: Nitelaf
limerick_list.text:
In Hold 'Em, a player may find
That she's caught in a bit of a bind:
She'll not bet quite enough
To succeed as a bluff,
And instead she'll get raised by the blind.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
Eventing's a sport without peer—
First dressage, then show jump a clear.
Next, rider and horse
Face the cross country course,
Which rightly fills many with fear.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
You say decine, dear Webster, to mean
A high alkyne, C10H15,
That's decenylene too.
For a term that is new
And rings true, cyclodecyne's now seen.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
The peaches are crushed, they are juiced:
The liquid is thereby educed,
Without change, from the fruit.
No one here can refute
That the nectar runs free—it is loosed.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The woman who joined your committee
Isn't serious, clever, or witty.
The committeemen say
She should stay anyway;
Do you think it's because she's so pretty?

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
The innkeeper found me a mess,
So I felt that I had to confess.
"I sure am a fool—
I jumped in your pool,
Never seeing it started with cess!"

limerick_list.author: creelbm
limerick_list.text:
East Indians hold in esteem
Their hardy mahogany, neem.
This arid tree's sprigs
Are eaten. Its twigs?
Bug repellant and toothbrush supreme!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It's an anticoagulant drug,
Just what's needed for saving this mug
Who has dangerous clots.
Give him Coumadin—lots!
If we don't, we'll be pulling the plug.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Clever Greek Alexandrian, Hero,
Took steam-jet propulsion from zero
To heat-hissing joys
Called aeolipiles, boys —
Then he sent some as toys to crazed Nero.

limerick_list.author: Cat
limerick_list.text:
If you've just fallen out with your friends
And you feel that you must make amends,
Say "I'm sorry" to start —
Say it right from the heart —
Then see how hostility ends!

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
They travel in hordes, not in pairs.
They're common, without snooty airs.
Like their tropical cousins,
They bite by the dozens.
Do bedbugs get jet lag? Who cares!

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
While my toddler makes strides in mobility,
I'm losing my speed and agility.
He flings toys on the floor
Making messes galore.
Cleaning up is an act of futility.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When my friend displayed grief that seemed deep,
I was shocked and asked, "Why do you weep?"
"We just euthanized Daniel;
Our old cocker spaniel
Had cancer—we put him to sleep."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Is unity just an abstraction?
Already, we've started to faction:
Turning backs, turning coats,
At our former friends' throats.
Still, I'm drawn to the heat of the action.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
Off the shelf the odd book she would pick;
This one's sweet smell of death made her sick.
The strange title was chilling:
Bad Folks Who Need Killing.
(Its ex libris: "Belongs to Old Nick.")

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
In Oz, down the gurgler, it's plain,
Means the same as to say "down the drain",
As not only won't water
Go down as it oughta
Down Under: life, too (it's a pain).

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Serving steaks with an Argentine sauce
Of chopped parsley and garlic, I toss
Herbs with chilies, salt, oil,
And vinegar—boy'll
Chimichurri impress my new boss.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
While at Mel's house, so ritzy and swank,
Bugs and Daffy devised quite a prank.
In his wine cellar, they
Altered labels to say
That now even the red's blank de Blanc.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I'm learning today how to frack.
I hope that I'll soon get the knack.
If I make the rock crack,
Much shale oil should flow back —
I hope soon: fracking's under attack.

limerick_list.author: C. H. Carpenter
limerick_list.text:
To the calf the new fence seemed quite strange:
Twisted strands between posts.  What a change!
Sharpened wires set to prick
Cut his nose to the quick.
The barbed wire made him moan on the range.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
When the phone rang, I panicked, all flustered,
And forgot to keep stirring the custard.
Agitated — that's me —
Like the custard should be!
Neither one of us now cuts the mustard.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
I was nervous, and cried when doc said,
"Your packed bowels mean trouble ahead.
It was June twenty-third
That you last passed a turd,
So, egest a bunch soon, or you're dead."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Pass the cheese tray!" he bellowed. "Of course,"
She replied, "You eat just like a horse!"
"Horses never eat cheese.
You've got masters' degrees,
But you're dumb!" Now she wants a divorce.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
The scout saw the enemy massed
For a charge up the hill, so, aghast,
He signaled by fire
Their approach (things looked dire).
Through his beacon, the foe was outclassed.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
First, the ass couldn't stay on his feet.
Now he's airing his paunch in the street.
Wasted drunk, wasted date,
And it's not even late!
He's passed out; now my evening's complete.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan Caws-Elwitt
limerick_list.text:
The waiter made quite an assumption.
I think it was quite a presumption.
It's just as I'd feared:
My plate has been cleared.
He sure had a whole lot of gumption!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Here's a word that's both odd and worthwhile:
To clapperclaw—"scold" or "revile."
It is also "to claw."
I revere it with awe,
As it makes me both tremble and smile.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Take a conjugate acid, e.g.
HCl, and deprotonate: see!
It's turned conjugate base —
Just Cl left in place,
Plus electron — the proton set free.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
In most modern buildings, the hall
Is open, both spacious and tall.
As atriums (atria)
They're where you wait, rea-
lizing they make you feel small.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
It's been talked of, imagined, yes, chased,
Called dangerous—finally traced.
Now I'm hungry to catch
Me a nice bandersnatch
For my stew-pot. I long for a taste.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Is he dead? I'll find out—let me check.
He can breathe, but his face is a wreck.
Blood's all over his head,
But I'll soon staunch the spread
With a tourniquet wrapped round his neck.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
When iron's not treated with care—
Left exposed to the rain and the air—
It will slowly explode
(More correctly, corrode),
Forming rust, a red, dusty affair.

limerick_list.author: Katherine Hooper
limerick_list.text:
There's a barrier between blood and brain
Semi-permeable, helping restrain
Stuff that isn't legit
(Or that simply won't fit),
But it doesn't inhibit cocaine.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
It feels like the hot fires of hell
Are fueling my fever; I well
May expire from the pain,
And I'm nearly insane.
"He was burned up," my gravestone will tell.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Early evening's when patience grows thinner:
Kids are home, but it's early for dinner.
Dispositions turn sour;
It's the arsenic hour.
The first to the table's the winner.

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
From his raft, aboriginal Louie
Tossed a float when my raft went kablooey.
His vocal display
I have called, to this day,
The Ocoee (a buoy to) cooey.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Your mother's a lifelong subscriber
To the cult that loves dietary fiber,
So don't  cry and sulk;
Eat your roughage and bulk.
That works better than money to bribe 'er.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
With her cheese cutter broken, Louise
Is beseeching her party guests, "Please,
We are all of us friends!"
But her question offends:
"Would you tell me now, who cut the cheese?"

limerick_list.author: Buonarotti
limerick_list.text:
Sing "The Old Rugged Cross" with the choir,
And your spirit soars higher and higher.
George, the Methodist bard,
Christian soldier, Bennard,
Wrote this song touched by heavenly fire.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Fierce Grendel's a monster who eats
Human beings, then finally meets
With an old superhero
Who leaves Grendel zero.
He's Beowulf, King of the Geats!

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
From the barbecue in my back yard
Comes food crispy and blackened and hard,
Singed and seared by the flame,
But I won't take the blame:
My good wife wants her burgers well charred.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Alliaceae? Truth I must tell:
It's the family with onions that smell.
Since the scent is too strong,
They no longer belong
With the lilies. Alone they should dwell.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
By the way, we'll be travelling my way:
An obscure and unfrequented by-way.
On a by-walk at dawn,
Faraway and withdrawn,
We will by-pass the well-travelled highway.

limerick_list.author: Jam Handy
limerick_list.text:
For pharmacists, math ain't for kicks;
It's used to determine the mix.
When we need to dilute
Or to reconstitute,
Alligation is one of our tricks.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Move the loot if you have any sense
To a pawn shop or, better, a fence.
When conditions turn prickly,
A fence will pay quickly.
His cut's just a business expense.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Beware Alternaria blight:
While it won't kill potatoes outright,
Early blight, you should know,
Is a tough row to hoe.
Would rotation of crops help? It might.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Reproduce without sex (that's monogony),
Or with ova and sperm (gametogony);
If the offspring you raise
Has an embryo phase,
Call the start of its life embryogony.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
A380's the biggest jet yet:
With this new superjumbo, you get
Over five hundred seats,
But the crowding defeats
The pleasures of travel by jet.

limerick_list.author: Scott Campisi
limerick_list.text:
You're aware of his slack disposition,
Yet you're paying his med-school tuition!
A physician? You're wishin'!
He lacks the ambition.
Aim lower.  I'm thinking musician.

limerick_list.author: matthewg
limerick_list.text:
I'm quite fond of a plant-killing spree.
Though a pro, I would murder for free.
When I find a fish tank
Which with algae is rank,
Adding algicide gives me much glee.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
The word funds may quite simply mean "money."
When keepers of bees sell some honey,
Gooey traces they wash
From their hands with panache,
For at banks sticky fingers ain't funny.

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Forget nuclear physics, I say.
Don't send diamond or carbide my way.
And philosophy? No.
Distilled booze I'll forgo,
Since I gave up the hard stuff in May.

limerick_list.author: Ellla B.
limerick_list.text:
The thread of my dream is oblique:
A pudding-laced caper antique,
Not of Swiss Miss or Jell-Os
Or Weird Harold fellows.
It's allemain acrobats seek.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
When you don't have Champagne, try Blanquette,
Which is just like the sparkling Clairette.
It is equally nice
At a much lower price.
(Or Crémant is as tasty, I bet.)

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
From Russia, they wandered away;
In Alaska, decided to stay.
The intrepid Aleuts
In their watertight boots
Settled down on an island array.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Kenneth Arnold cannot have been glad
That the sighting he made spawned a fad.
On his cross-country flight,
He saw discs shining bright,
Speeding faster than jets could. Egad!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
He said he'd come round about noonish.
He arrived, and I thought him cartoonish.
Quite a blind date surprise:
Giant head, popping eyes,
But the worst was he acted buffoonish.

limerick_list.author: David and Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A giraffe-necked remarkable dame
From Rangoon has attained wide acclaim.
With her twenty-third ring,
They have found she can sing
A high C that puts divas to shame.

limerick_list.author: limarico
limerick_list.text:
"Dear dressmaker, make me a dress."
"Ah, but, sir, you're a man, more or less.
And your small fabric piece
Wouldn't cover my niece.
You're a dozen times bigger, I'd guess."

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Said the Queen, "To one wish we must cling:
That some day we'll possess just one thing.
We would like a man's balls,
Since our lack of them galls.
If we just had a pair, we'd be King."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
He gets jilted and goes on a binge,
Drinks so much that it makes people cringe.
When his drinking stops, he's
Got a case of D.T.'s,
With his mind in a state of unhinge.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The god Bacchus, now withered and aged,
In old Rome had led troupes that engaged
In both sex and strong drink,
Which today we would think
Had debacchated—lustily raged.

limerick_list.author: pkwooster
limerick_list.text:
The crosshairs can help with your aim;
Without them it's just not the same.
If you line up the hairs
On rabbits or bears,
You'll return to the lodge with more game.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
This young cerealist's days are all spent
In the fields far from cold, hard cement.
There she sows and maintains
A rich medley of grains.
They don't chat much, but still she's content.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Some deficiency diseases are due
To a vitamin lack. While it's true
Scurvy's caused by low C,
And rickets low D,
What causes low T? Wish I knew.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
She despairingly begged for our ear,
For we execute murderers here.
She had slaughtered her man,
But it wasn't her plan —
She just held the knife; he came too near!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
We'd tried peace talks; they hadn't succeeded.
Further fence-mending surely was needed.
We PMs, then, swapped wives,
Which changed all our dull lives:
Furrows formerly fallow are seeded.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
She typed "BBFN." I thought, "Wow!
She is telling me 'Bye-bye for now.'
I remember back when
She'd type 'TTFN.'
She is really maturing, and how!"

limerick_list.author: Snowy Owl
limerick_list.text:
If word choices cause you frustration,
Be tricky and try affixation.
From store, get restore,
Storage, storing, and more —
Like substoral, my latest creation.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
Should you remonstrate, WE,
That my limerick's rubbish, you'll see
How I counter-attack,
How I remonstrate back:
A contraremonstrant — that's me!

limerick_list.author: Bob Egg
Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Dissatisfaction is what you might feel
At the end of a poorly cooked meal,
Or when you discover
The ring from your lover
Was made with a stone that's not real.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
All this factional strife is a curse,
Each group swearing the other is worse.
Let dissenters agree
To just live and let be—
Or we'll all travel home in a hearse.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Poor Mappy! — (that's Pamela) Phelps:
Her dyslexia means that she slelps
Her words slightly awry
And she can't play Spy-I.
(You don't have to be mab, but it helps.)

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Discontinuer though I may be,
Quitting church was a bonus for me.
I keep more of my pay,
Since it's not tithed away,
And my Sundays I always have free.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Now for me, I say nature's barbed wire,
As the pain from its thorns is quite dire,
Though firethorn, too,
Is a good name. It's true
Pyracantha's the blackbird's desire.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Examine this limerick: you'll find
A neat puzzle uniquely designed.
It's got style and, what's more,
With eighteenth at its core,
Definition and word are combined.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
I have heard bird of Jove means "an eagle,"
A bird that's decidedly regal.
What's called bird of Juno?
A peacock—now you know.
(Does Mercury dog mean "a beagle"?)

limerick_list.author: Dick C. Erd
limerick_list.text:
What a love the old couple expressed:
Swapped antiques before going to rest!
He gave darlingest Meg
His old hickory leg.
He was thrilled with her big cedar chest.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Degenerative ("tending to worsen")
Can name a disease in a person
Which causes decay
Of his tissues; he may
Suffer pain that'll generate cursin'.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
As conservator, Bill has the will
To protect all the trees in Brazil
From deforestation,
Though much of that nation
Is engaged in such practices still.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When you're resting, and let your eyes close,
And relaxing in peaceful repose,
One is likely to see,
On your brain EEG,
It's the time when the alpha wave shows.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Cave crickets consume themselves when
They run all out of food, now and then.
If they lack other remedies,
They'll eat their extremities
Even though they won't grow back again.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
The guy from FX thinks he's slick,
And a top-grossing movie's his shtick.
His results aren't pretty;
He levels the city.
That's known as a blockbuster flick.

limerick_list.author: Mary and SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The complaint was not clatter but clutter
That caused my dear husband to mutter,
"Are these kids really mine?
All my instincts incline
Me to throw out their junk in the gutter."

limerick_list.author: Lawrence A. Herman
limerick_list.text:
An enantiomorphic connection
Resembles a mirror's reflection.
The form of the first
Is the second, reversed.
You've a pair close at hand for inspection.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
In a land where no bluebloods are bred,
Aussie bloodnuts, though "Blue", will bleed red.
See, like fatties named "Slim"
And young "Einstein", who's dim,
Redheads answer to "Bluey" instead.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
'Midst the sugar beets, soybeans, and corn
Is Bay City, a little well-worn.
It's important, in short,
As a Michigan port
(And the place where Madonna was born).

limerick_list.author: Nan
limerick_list.text:
Go higher and higher and higher —
Aconcagua's tough summit acquire.
This Andean peak
Could make you so weak
You might hear a heavenly choir.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
I borrowed a page from his book
As, determined, by hook or by crook,
To learn from the best
(Yes this was my quest) —
I did just what he does, see? Look!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I suffer a form of displacement—
A friend-induced psychic effacement.
Feeling humbled and low,
I've decided to go
And reside like a schmo in abasement.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
You, go swim or else oar some canoe;
Those are things that will put me askew.
That stuff's not my turf—
My bailiwick's surf!
It's the only sport I love to do.

limerick_list.author: Carole Lyons
limerick_list.text:
Aldrovanda is plant life—aquatic,
Free-floating, and yet systematic.
Insectivorous traits
Mean the food it awaits
Makes the bug life in bogs quite traumatic.

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
After losing his job, in lament he
Said, "Agism? I have seen plenty.
'Help wanted,' ads say,
'Please apply here, today!'
But only for those who look twenty."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Commie-bashers are not fond of Reds.
D.C.-bashers? The same, but with Feds.
Any group you can name—
The construction's the same:
Add this word and hostility spreads.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
"If you miss this last game-winning basket,"
The coach said, "I won't blow a gasket.
I'll just rip out your heart,
Tear your body apart,
And then bury your bits in a casket."

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
A lens with chromatic aberrations
Gives problems in some situations.
Its image's fringes
Have strange coloured tinges,
Which causes bizarre complications.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Said a cardsharp, "I know how you feel.
You've been robbed by an odious heel."
Then he took what was left,
Leaving Queenie bereft.
"Just another," she sighed, "dirty deal."

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
If you stare at a cloudless blue sky,
You will see tiny flashes flit by.
This blue-field entoptic
Phenomenon optic-
ally demonstrates cells in your eye.

limerick_list.author: Jean McEwen
limerick_list.text:
Forrest Timberman works as a frogger—
(That means the same thing as a "logger.")
He loads up the lumber,
Toils for hours without slumber.
This guy—he works hard.  Not a slogger.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Homemade papers are coarse-grained, some buff,
And some  deckled, with edges so rough.
Some look torn—no alarm—
That's  their primitive charm,
So  some people just can't get enough.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
A boy on my sidewalk in Yonkers
Would smash all the other boys' conkers
With only one chestnut.
We called him "the best nut"
Because he was totally bonkers.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I'm in trouble and, boy, does it sting!
The majority party (left wing)
Raised my taxes.  Know what?
It's a kick in the butt.
Nearly broke, I've my ass in a sling.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In my grandfather's testament, he
Left the family business to me
In the hope it would stay
In a family way,
But it's now Donald Trump's acquiree.

limerick_list.author: Carole Lyons
limerick_list.text:
Said a hip college junior named Stan,
"I dig archaeology, man!
I rock in geology,
Mars (areology),
And I've studied abroad—in my van."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Jack's AWTF, the poor guy.
"That's "away with the fairies," I sigh.
He seems lost and confused
So this shorthand is used
To imply he needs help to get by.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
You're contemplative? Feel in the mood
For deep thoughts? Have a tendence to brood?
If I can't make your day
With my jokes, then I'd say
You're in need of a nap, or some food.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Counterespionage is a must
In a world full of folks we can't trust.
When trying to thwart
Foreign spies, we'll resort
To some methods that can't be discussed.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Neuroleptics are used when a life
Suffers dire psychological strife.
For these powerful tranqs,
Many schizos give thanks,
Since delusions no longer are rife.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
The homeless man's shirt was all dinge:
Crumbs of food and a cigarette's singe.
It was dirty as hell —
Not to mention the smell
Of the vomit he spewed on a binge.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
You should always be sure to accredit
A statement when someone else said it.
Provide information
Re: its publication,
To give the appearance you've read it.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
An old pirate, the day he turned eighty,
Noticed something quite neat, if not weighty.
No more seventy-nine,
He could now say this line
With a new hidden meaning: "Aye, matey!"

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
In the hills out in Tamil Nadu
There are so many fun things to do,
Like Badaga Scrabble,
But don't let the rabble
Make a Kannada goose out of you.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When she'd run out of food and of fuel,
His assistance enabled renewal.
Now her needlework gift
Gives the donor a lift—
The return for his kindness is crewel.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
An achievement age, teachers will state,
Is a benchmark that's used to relate
How your child will progress
As life's tasks they assess:
Walk by one, count at four, swear by eight.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The marquis has concubinary ways.
All his mistresses' bills? The guy pays.
In a house near the gate
Of his pater's estate,
They live gratefully, singing his praise.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
It seems contronym words are quite rare
And have opposite meanings — beware:
As I passed by a store,
In the window I saw
That "The Chemist Dispenses With Care".

limerick_list.author: Bit
limerick_list.text:
My chemical compound is bare.
It is lacking that singular flair.
With a bang and a hiss,
I'll acetylate this;
Got a group of acetyl to spare?

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
"Blocked up ear canals? Oh, what a pain.
So, a problem? Less sound to your brain?"
My poor friend simply sighed,
Moved in close and replied,
"Pardon me, could you say that again?"

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
If your textbook has words you don't know,
Then the glossary's where you should go.
That's a place you can look
Near the end of the book.
Definitions are what it will show.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A breaker's a dohickey which is
Automatically opening switches
When a powerful surge
Puts it over the verge,
Thus preventing electrical glitches.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I pick up my shoes on the run,
And the cobbler pronounces them done.
But what once were size 8s
Are now 4s, so he states:
"Half a loafer is better than none!"

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
I'm an Aaronite, a.k.a. Cohen.
All Moses' bro's boy-line still goin'
Are born to be priestly,
Which could be quite beastly
If goats still on altars were thrown.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
"Take your bandy legs back to Dundee,"
Said the Major, and spluttered his tea.
"I should thrash you, of course,
If you weren't on your horse.
Do you dare bandy insults with me?"

limerick_list.author: John Weigel
limerick_list.text:
For John Milton there was a strong need
Through Areopagitica's screed
To tell Parliament
They all ought to repent
And not censor the stuff they don't read.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
If you bend it like Beckham the more
Winning goals you are likely to score.
Make it swerve; watch it spin.
Throw a curve; take 'em in.
Face your fans! Punch the air! Hear 'em roar!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's the ape, ram, olm, boa, bee, cat,
Ono, elk, cod, ewt, pug, pig, tom, rat,
Plus the ide, pen, auk, jay,
Fly, ewe, tit, yak, fox, ray,
Owl, dab, orc, hog, hen, emu, gar, bat.

Then there's man, the tod, tui, roe, kob,
Ant, doe, ani, gib, dzo, eel, tup, hob,
Gnu, ass, dog, elo, sow,
Goa, asp, teg, roo, cow,
Ayu, koi, ahi, kea, and cob.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
zqms
limerick_list.text:
Golden weddings are seldom these days,
And a couple, once married, that stays
Together that long
(Fifty years) must be strong,
Many others go separate ways.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
If a crapehanger darkens the room
With an attitude driven by gloom,
The good news that you savor
To him seems much graver,
And portentously signals your doom.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
Joe spends ten hours a day at the gym.
This surely must enervate him,
But the wedge shape he's honing
Will have the chicks moaning
Should he muster the strength for a swim.

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
"We can never be sure, at the best,"
Acatalepsy, the Skeptics professed.
Every answer's "We guess,"
Never straight "No," or "Yes,"
So they wouldn't do well on a test.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When a hunter harpoons them, they thrash a lot.
They're so huge, one would think they would crash a lot,
But though large, these sperm whales
Steer quite well with their tails—
So it's whaling that threatens the cachalot.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A counterexample disproves
One's hypothesis, thus it behooves
You to quit with your rants
On how white guys can't dance
And get in here and check out my moves.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
See Cupid's swift arrows bestow
Wondrous love; they set hearts all aglow.
May he reach in his quiver
And surely deliver
His arrow from bow to your beau.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
Cahors is a town on the Lot,
In south-western France, where it's hot.
Its bridge is well known
As a marvel in stone,
And its brash, fruity wine hits the spot.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
My goglet's a horn drinking cup;
From its lip, full-strength liquor I sup.
It was made from a cow—
Yes, she's quite hornless now,
She's the meat that we chow. Do drink up.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
For a year, her sick brother she nursed,
Yet got nothing when funds were disbursed.
All it said in his will:
"My sincere 'Thanks' to Jill."
It was then that she stamped, screamed and cursed!

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
"It's arrhythmia, that's what you've got,"
Said the doctor, who knew on the spot.
It seems that my heart
Needs a kick just to start.
(Like my scooter, which breaks down a lot.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
To his sleigh through the snowbank, see Santa lope;
He's replacing the reindeer with antelope,
Which consist of a gnu,
An impala or two,
And a kudu who's chewing a cantaloupe.

limerick_list.author: Scott Campisi
limerick_list.text:
My transsexual cousin named Claude
Said, "The girls overseas would applaud
My new life as a beau."
But then, what does he know?
Cousin Claude's never once been abroad.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
There's south-eastern Australia beneath
A low shrub one calls cranberry heath.
It has reddish, ripe fruit
With delicious repute:
A sweet treat on the tongue side of teeth.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
When my broker informed me he'd bought
Baby bonds, "Good investment!" I thought.
My retirement's now planned
With these notes near a grand,
And my life fills with interest they've brought.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"For the boys' room, a bunk bed," said Mother.
"That's two beds—one stacked on the other."
But I doubt she will buy one.
I'd fall from the high one,
Or, sleeping, I'd pee on my brother.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Lynne, our intern, is useless, expendable.
We had hoped she'd be smart and  dependable,
But she shirks and she flirts—
All her work's done in spurts.
On the whole, this new clerk's discommendable.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
The clouds are as dark as your bruise,
Suffused with dark purples and blues.
But your bruise will turn green,
Maybe beige or citrine.
It's allochroous, changing its hues.

limerick_list.author: Snowy Owl
limerick_list.text:
