After years of toil, aches and travail —
Working long, spending short, growing frail —
This great lottery win
Means the fun can begin,
Now the good life is mine: cakes and ale!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I'm a day student; Morty's a boarder.
The dorm captain acts as his warder.
I go home every night
And get high as a kite,
While the boarding school keeps him in order.

limerick_list.author: hugh t.
limerick_list.text:
The Golden Fleece — that was the cargo
That Jason shipped home in the Argo;
Here's the speech made in port
By the bold argonaut:
************************1

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Disobedience, when it is civil,
Is refusal to kowtow to drivel
The government says
(Like, "We're banning all PEZ").
We'll protest until attitudes swivel.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
Said Noah, "We've too much liquidity
Round this ark, so it seems that God did it; he
Said that he'd found
We were fit to be drowned;
Now he's absolute in his humidity."

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
It was "Bear Night" in Glasgow, all-male.
Up comes Broxi Bear, mascot! I hail:
"Are you hot in that fur?"
He responds with: "Am ur.
Ah'm pure fit. Gonnae check oot ma tail?"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Signor Luria comes from Liguria,
Sees a doctor, complains of dysuria.
After taking a test,
He gets news that is best:
"All it shows is a mild cylindruria."

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
"Wha'sa matter?" he slurred alcoholically.
"I'm upset," she replied melancholically.
"I'm sick of your drinking,
Your breath always stinking,"
And she raved on and on vitriolically.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
You click on a button and find
That you've come to a web page designed
By a colour-blind smurf
Who's asleep on some turf,
And the sight of it's turning you blind!

limerick_list.author: sl8ofhand
limerick_list.text:
When she's asked to describe hubby's flaws,
Mrs. Claus lists her elfin in-laws.
They want grandchildren clausal
Though she's post-menopausal!
He's hoping this frostiness thaws...

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I'm a man with a dog, and I'm blue
Cuz he's old and he's sick, and I rue.
There are times when a man
Does the best that he can,
So I'll do what a man has to do.

limerick_list.author: Chavi Beck
limerick_list.text:
There once was a girl from New York
Who complained, "No one likes how I talk!"
With an attitude cruddy,
She kvetched, "You sound nutty!
Don't mock how I talk! Take a walk!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The word dogtrick—its sound can evoke
Something sneaky, a practical joke,
One that's nasty and churlish
(Not cute, sweet, or girlish).
It's more of a poke than a stroke.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
As I run 'round the circle, I'll tap
Every head, calling "Duck, duck..." Don't nap,
Stay alert, watch your head —
If you're "Goose" then you're dead.
You'll be left with a lake in your lap.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The G-Clefs (four brothers, one friend),
Had two hits: one, "Ka-Ding Dong," they penned,
And "I Understand," one
The Four Tunes group had done;
"Auld Lang Syne" is the back-vocal blend.

limerick_list.author: Alison Hunt
limerick_list.text:
Bill Porter was such a big cheese:
So important, he never said please.
He shouted and blustered,
Left many folk flustered,
Never learning to put them at ease.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Our friend Poppo is pope!" Friends would shout it
On hearing the good news about it.
Back in 1048,
Did he win with the great
Slogan: "Poppo for Pope-o"? I doubt it.

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
I hope you don't find it too odd
When you see I've no clothes on my bod.
Adamitism means
I don't wear any jeans
Because I'm going naked for God.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
In Paris the tarts hit the bricks
From noon until just about six.
Afternoon, they would say,
Is midi through après,
And the time for pâtisserie tricks.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
I embellished my resume, boss.
That means "fancied it up with some gloss."
Sanitation Director
(I'm a garbage collector)
Is a stretch, but the gist comes across.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
School is out, so let's throw us a bash.
I can brace Uncle Buck for the cash.
Though old Buck's no soft touch,
I won't ask him for much—
Just remind him he flashed me his stash.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The King's offspring I mean to disprince
(Bring him down), but I'll have to convince
The King's Council he's bad,
And would poison his dad—
Just the thought makes His Majesty wince.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
At Gitmo the law came unhinged,
With the rights of the captives infringed.
The Commander-in-Chief
Professed disbelief
When the Statue of Liberty cringed.

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
If you're feeling all sickly and weak,
Here's a simple, safe treatment technique
To get rid of your sloth:
Sip a strong clear meat broth.
That's cullis, the cure that you seek.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
You're calm, unconcerned, and you're mellow,
But I think you should worry, young fellow.
You're jaundiced, dear Eric—
An anti-icteric
Might make you look somewhat less yellow.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"A young swan? What a beautiful thing!
There are six in my moat," said the king.
"Can we teach them to go
In a circle? If so,
I will christen it this: cygnet ring."

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
King Ahaz's failures were many.
He worshipped unwisely, and then he
Was hated by neighbors.
The last of his labors?
The Lord wasn't left with a penny.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Brutish boors will engage in baboonery;
Though clownlike, their aim's not buffoonery.
But a real baboon's treat,
When in estrus (that's heat),
Is some moonery Junery spoonery.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Fertility drugs: medication
That's used to promote stimulation
Of follicle growth
In the ovaries — both.
They help couples achieve procreation.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
When you're fission (a popular sport),
Use debate, or you'll find you're caught short.
Dig some up; just go vermin —
Keep them squiggly and squirmin' —
Or buy blood worms in town by deport.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
In a room at the end of the hall,
Bluebeard's wife (number seven) found all
Of the previous six
Highly moribund chicks.
She herself had a very close call.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Asked the beer drinker spending his time
Down in Mexico's balmier clime,
"What's this dreck in the neck
Of my Beck's? Would you check?
I don't drink my cerveza with lime."

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Our Queen's overtaken Victoria,
Hence the media's sudden euphoria.
For 63 years
Seven months, she's heard cheers:
In excelsis, Elizabeth, Gloria!

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
During seder, my uncle confessed
He'd become with a shiksa obsessed.
Said his son, "Oy vey, Faddah!"
And dropped his Haggadah.
"Pass over her—give it a rest!"

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
In the dining room's where you should eat,
At the table, ensconced in your seat—
Not in front of the box
In your boxers and socks,
With the dog licking crumbs off your feet.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
As the Lord of a lofty domain,
High regard from my subjects I gain.
In my tenement flat,
Monkey, rabbit and rat
All respect my domanial reign.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
In a desert, so hot that it hurt,
Desert islands of men kept alert.
Though it's duty they hate,
Just deserts will await
Any soldier who tries to desert.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
America First was a group
Who insisted we not send one troop
To help fight Europe's wars,
Since their plight's not our cause —
Pearl Harbor knocked that for a loop.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Antiques Roadshow's my vice, I confess.
I've a house full of junk—it's a mess.
I conjecture, with pleasure,
Each vase is a treasure
As weekly I watch PBS.

limerick_list.author: Seth Brown
limerick_list.text:
What's a breeder? It's one who will breed
Pets or livestock—they'll give them some feed,
Help the beasts reproduce.
But as slang, the word's use
Is what gay folks call straights, so take heed.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
"Like a fish" is the phrase to describe
How they drink in the Carides tribe.
Shrimp and prawns are enamored
Of drinking 'til hammered—
The decapod way to imbibe.

limerick_list.author: jexia
limerick_list.text:
For casual, the outfit's a shirt,
Comfy jeans, and some shoes that don't hurt.
For business, a suit
Lets you dress gender-neut,
And for party?  A seven-inch skirt.

limerick_list.author: Bill Dorner
limerick_list.text:
Every egg tastes the same as its brother,
But with donuts there's always another,
So for brunch I'd prefer
(And perhaps you'd concur)
Half of one and six dozen the other.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
For our monarch, we use the word Crown,
As an adjective, also a noun.
And the king's coronet
Is a crown—better yet—
It's the top of his head (looking down).

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Denticulation is commonly found
When describing an edge, or surround,
Finely toothed or serrated.
It's sometimes related
To leaves having margins thus crowned.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Doing acid on President's Day,
A hippie was trippy till May.
Now he always requests
Acidimeter tests
So the dope doesn't blow him away.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
In the meantime, the stew'd lost its charm; it's
Unseemly that Chuck come to harm. It's
A lock that they knew
Different strokes wouldn't do,
So they chucked the whole mess to the marmots.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Rep. Jim Jordan can raise quite a racket
When he jumps on the truth to attack it.
Spouting falsehoods quite loudly,
He often lies proudly.
Won't somebody get him a jacket?

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
The mobsters, thick-muscled and scarred,
Hold old Will in the highest regard.
In the show Kiss Me, Kate,
This advice they relate:
It behooves you to brush up your Bard.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
From Remembrance Day, what do we learn —
And what good did the armistice earn?
For though poppies descend,
How can your grieving end
If your loved one was not to return?

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I've some films that my doc let me borrow
To help me to deal with my sorrow.
I don't know what to think
When I hear from my shrink:
"Take two dramas and call me tomorrow."

limerick_list.author: Jonathan Gearhart
limerick_list.text:
The humble man's message is great,
One that rock stars should try to create.
"Don't be puffing your chest
Or your head. To sing best,
It's your diaphragm you should efflate!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
You weren't there when the mob boss was whacked,
But a hideout the killer then lacked.
You said, "Hide 'neath the floor
Of my outhouse." Well, you're
An accessory after the fact.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Though some feel the future is shapable,
The facts lead to doom inescapable:
The reactor's great vault
That the Greens couldn't halt
Has been built on a fault, and it's capable.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
No one's died or resigned and, it's true,
Red's still red, just as blue is still blue.
There's no chance, even vague,
Of a flood or a plague;
Nothing earthshaking. How about you?

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
That seven-starred, clear constellation
Has a name that can cause consternation:
The Plough (then again,
It was once called Charles' Wain)
Or Big Dipper, the Yanks' variation.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
A word that I've seldom seen used
Is one that has left me bemused.
The word is confuzzled,
But does it mean puzzled?
(Or simply a little confused?)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
She is gracious and graceful and smart,
And in China our love had its start.
In the capital city,
I'm singing this ditty:
"Beijing Went the Strings of My Heart."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
They're at home in the sea and on land,
Finding water and air to be grand.
Such amphibiousness
Is the key to success
When some swim to the strand and then stand.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Lumbar vertebrae now have a kink
So I'm seeking some help 'fore I sink
'neath the pain. Will the bend
In my back never mend,
Or be cured in a blink, do you think?

limerick_list.author: Harris Risman
limerick_list.text:
I'm a luftmensch, a person of air,
And the gas in my lungs is the fare
That I eat. Food and shelter?
That comes helter-skelter;
It's how I live life. I don't care.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Your voice in this church? Not exalting.
You're failing, but you I'm not faulting.
One just can't sound superb
When arched (curved) roofs reverb;
It's so sad that your voice is revaulting.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
An old codger, with mien geriatric,
Laced his skates in a gesture theatric.
Dropped his cane, took the ice,
Loosened up in a trice,
And went on to complete a mean hat trick.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
As a poet, her writing's artistic;
A melange of romantic and mystic.
And she always prefers,
When the option is hers,
To be known as soignee, belletristic.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I often eat comfort food.  Stress
Is the trigger to make me regress
To my childhood and make
What my mom used to bake.
Over time, my weight grew to excess.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Cosmological principle's fame
Puts Copernican brother to shame:
It proclaims with some nerve
Wheresoe'er you observe
In the cosmos, it all looks the same.

limerick_list.author: cecelia
limerick_list.text:
"When I light this ear candle you'll find
It will draw out debris of all kind."
Cried the boy feeling shaky,
"I like earwax cakey...
And what if it sucks out my mind?"

limerick_list.author: pkwooster
limerick_list.text:
Close-hauled, nearly into the wind,
She was pointing — the skipper just grinned.
If we trim the sails right,
A sure win is in sight.
If they luff, he will roar we have sinned.

limerick_list.author: sl8ofhand
limerick_list.text:
Supermodels are taught to act haughtily,
To show off their assets quite bawdily;
And to turn and look back
At the lens-toting pack
To ensure that the camera's aimed caudally.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
That familiarizing effect's what men miss
When they seek out a street girl for bliss.
There's no kiss, hug, or foreplay —
No asking for more play.
(Hmm.  Home's not much different from this…)

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
An addled-brained lad from Key Largo,
Desiring to transport some cargo,
Arranged an affreightment
But made a misstatement.
The consequence? Total embargo.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A Bulgarian's middle-aged spread
Garners fame, to his countrymen's dread:
He's a round-the-clock slouch
And attached to his couch,
Which they're calling a Sofia bed.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
A bluesman who bugled the blues
Blew his best, but his blues met with boos.
So he bootlegged some brews —
Got depressed on the booze:
A blue bluesman with boozy boohoos.

limerick_list.author: lopey
limerick_list.text:
With an arsonous gleam in my eye,
Someone's shoe I just happened to spy
With a hole in the toe
Where the matches would go.
How delightful his screams! "Ay yi yi!"

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
That urology doctor-trainee
With the cystourethroscope, see,
Unsuccessfully tried
To observe the inside
Of the bladder that's holding your pee.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
It's a mantis that has special power
To help it catch prey to devour.
Other insects come near
Its strong forelegs sans fear
'Cause it's camouflaged: looks like a flower.

limerick_list.author: buttonbright
limerick_list.text:
You'll pray for the patience of Job
If you've married an agoraphobe.
It pains him to face
The mobbed marketplace,
So he sits round the house in his robe.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
Well, at first I was truly enamoured,
When she bumped into me while she stammered,
"Yes, I l-l-love you, my dear!"
And that's when I smelt beer
On her breath. She was plastered—yes, hammered.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
A parachute jumper he's not.
In this movie, no airplane you'll spot.
There's no free-falling guy
Dropping out of the sky.
That's a chutist.  This shootist gets shot.

limerick_list.author: jsolomon
limerick_list.text:
The artiste with his famed entourage
Liked to demonstrate making collage.
With his odd scraps of tin
And old rags he'd begin
To assemble a piece "en garage."

limerick_list.author: Chavi Beck
limerick_list.text:
When Antiochus banned Torah study,
My chavrusa (my study hall buddy)
Shlepped our scrolls to a cave
In Judea. He's brave!
But that tale of the dreidel? Too nutty.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
First the tale of some kid and a dame,
The strip Abbie an' Slats soon became
More about this old guy
With a glint in his eye:
"Bathless" Groggins (one heck of a name).

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Though my boss is a dimwit, I say
Nothing bad.  My tongue's bitten each day.
My contempt he won't see.
If I nod and agree,
In this lucrative job I can stay.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Once a popular touristy spot,
Acapulco's become just "too hot".
Fear and killings are laid
To the heavy drug trade.
The cruel gangs show no heart, not a jot.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
At the altar, the bride looked a belle,
But they couldn't afford a hotel
For the bun fight that followed.
Their pride was soon swallowed:
Church halls make good venues, as well.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Just an "O" on a stick, but I'm fond
Of this gadget that makes me respond
With the sweet, soapy joy
That I felt as a boy
When I'm waving my old bubble wand.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
It was dubitable, open to doubt
(Not a word that I bandy about).
Now, indubitably, yes,
I've heard once, I confess,
But both words I could well live without.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Tom's swift mount lacked a thoroughbred's grace.
At the track he seemed quite out of place.
Crude jockeys cursed coarsely,
But Tom countered hoarsely,
"My steed will indeed win the race."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There is little that might make me gladder
Than curing this pain in my bladder.
My cystalgia's the pits.
I assure you that it's
Guaranteed to make anyone sadder.

limerick_list.author: PGS
Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Disencharm me, oh Wizard!  You granted
My wish with a spell that you planted.
Now the babes that I draw
Talk and talk — major flaw.
Set me free!"  (I became disenchanted.)

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
I've an option on "Putting and Pitch"
(They make golf clubs for folks who are rich).
If it doesn't reach five,
Out the window I'll dive.
Option trading can make life a bitch.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
A blood-curdling howl from the Scottie
(That is virtually true: blood got clotty!)
To our ears was traumatic.
Damn dog's operatic,
A terrier-ist Pavarotti!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The first task? Removing the faceplate
(That large plate on the front). Next the baseplate.
There's a raceway for wires
In our way — get your pliers
And unfasten what I call the "raceplate".

limerick_list.author: FlippingMackerel
limerick_list.text:
In the old days, a guy could comprint.
It means print alongside; there's a hint
There of ties that will bind—
If you willingly signed
Your own name to another guy's stint.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
You found oil; now you're drilling a well,
And the drill rig you're using is swell.
Though the rig's not too big,
Man, that drill bit can dig;
It can drill down to China—or Hell!

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
Ahinadab, Solomon's rep,
Tried hard not to make a false step,
Which was noble, except
He was wholly inept—
That's how Solomon coined the term schlep.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
It's said beauty is seen through the eyes
Of beholders, and that's no surprise.
What is ugly to some
Is held up as a plum
Among others—which reason defies.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Evil memories came like a thief.
They stole happiness, leaving me grief.
Now my mind has gone blank —
I have liquor to thank.
To forgetfulness! Blessed relief.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Among carpets, this carpet's a queen,
Even though it is made by machine.
Loops of wool sewn on linen
(Its strong underpinnin')
Make it great—Brussels carpet, I mean.

limerick_list.author: VERaLOE
limerick_list.text:
"The Esquiline Hill (Esquilino)
And the Aventine Hill (Aventino)
Are two hills of seven
In Rome (where it's heaven
To sit with a large cappuccino).

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
In the hot tub, what product to use
To sanitize? Two different views.
Given chlorine's strong smell,
Making that a hard sell,
I think bromine is what I should choose.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Deep-sixed many miles out at sea—
Food for fish, and his soul can go free.
I suppose we all know
That his god willed it so.
Now a show trial's just not gonna be.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My love for this stuff is extreme.
On a pudding or cake, it's supreme.
While I sleep, so it seems,
In my happiest dreams,
I am feasting on Devonshire cream.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
"I'll give you my candid opinion,"
Said a cannibal chief to his minion.
"What each person should do
To reduce CO2
Is convert to an anthropophaginian."

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
"Good heavens. That's cause for concern,"
Says the captain—and soon his men learn:
If you crew the Titanic,
It's too late to panic
When the boss commands, "Full steam astern!"

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
Andorra's the cause of my smiles.
It's one hundred and eighty square miles.
In the Pyrenees high,
With France and Spain nigh,
It calls to me—even beguiles.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
2,4-Dinitrophenol (can be
Also written 2,4-DNP):
Explosive, or doping,
Abused by those hoping
For weight loss, or blasting a tree.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
We should smash every shield that's pro-white,
And pro-black, for that's also not right.
So let's crack our warm jokes
About any darn folks
Because humour's a source of delight.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
If God would remove all the hues
And discolorize Earth, then I'd lose
Stunning sunsets and scenery,
Garden-grown greenery—
All I'd be left with? The blues.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
I feel peaceful whenever I look
At this painting. A lake or a brook
Has some deer at the side.
There are mountains so wide
And a waterfall back in a nook.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
As I'd strolled through mum's palace I'd seen a
Young gal with a stunning demeanour.
"I love you!" I'd sighed,
But this vision replied,
"Cor blimey! I'm only the cleaner."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
I'd dispose of some verbs if I could.
They refuse to behave as they should.
The verb can is defective
From a usage perspective:
Missing parts in a verb can't be good.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Here we are with the Princess of Song
In her home!" (This decor is all wrong.
Lord, that rug's beat to hell.
So's the furniture. Well,
We won't dwell on her dwelling too long.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A caffer cat's one that is feral.
They're, of monkeys, more fun than a barrel.
Found in Africa, Asia—
Their claws will amaze ya.
You cuddle these things at your peril!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
No killers are we; no debt owe.
But when sentenced to life, what we sow
Are the seeds of our dying.
For no one's denying
We're born, every one, on death row.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
After dropping my lunch tray in school,
I'm attempting to not lose my cool.
Quick as lightning I yank
Up my french fries and frank.
I'm employing the five-second rule!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
To discern Deena's meaning I tried:
"Oh, my boa's," she'd sighed, "double-dyed."
I inquired, to be nice,
"Did your snake drop dead twice?"
"No, my stole's two-times-tinted," she cried.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
You serve, I return with a dink
(This will certainly make your eyes blink).
I play softly, and yet
The ball's over the net,
Then abruptly it's starting to sink.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
"Gadzooks!" cried St George from his horse.
"That dragon displays no remorse!
I'm amazed — that I am! —
That he's eaten a lamb ...
And a princess, it seems, is next course!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Is a fabricatress someone to prize,
Or a woman I'd tend to despise?
One who labors and makes
Useful things, or who fakes?
Does she build things or does she tell lies?

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
You are planning to grind some tin ore?
It's a chore you abhor? It's a bore?
I will lend you my crazing-mill;
Just try this amazing mill.
"It's great! I adore it," you'll roar.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
It's the fault of his shirt, which was red, Jim:
A stone has impacted his head, Jim.
His brain was displaced
By silicon-based
Amphibolite (hornblende): He's dead, Jim.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Billy dressed up as "12" Halloween
While his sister went out as "15".
"That figures," I thought
Since their father has taught
Mathematics at Yale as their dean.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
"On the square", that's your claim? Shake my hand,
And it's then I can tell where we stand.
Just from that, and your stance,
I can tell, at a glance,
If you're getting the job, or you're banned.

limerick_list.author: neilski
SusanL
limerick_list.text:
He's guilty, that fact's indisputable.
His sentence I fear's not commutable.
No pardon is coming.
The Gov won't be slumming
With murdering thieves—it's unsuitable.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
This well-designed catheter's great,
As it comes in a pre-lubèd state.
With its coudé (curved) tip,
It can ease a long trip
Down a path that is not at all straight.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Your denigratory comments defame
Mr. Crist. In your whisper campaign,
As you badmouth, talk smack,
He can't even talk back;
You are giving the guy a bad name.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Acquacotta's the name of a soup.
Want the recipe? Here's the real scoop
Passed from mother to daughter:
Cook veggies in water,
Pour on bread and add cheese.  Serves a troop!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"While I wait, I take walks in the forest.
I've become an accomplished guitarist;
But the throne's what I'm seeking.
Politically speaking,
I remain a fanatical czarist."

limerick_list.author: Jean McEwen
limerick_list.text:
Is the carcajou greedy and mean?
Well, the glutton (you know, wolverine)
Loves to scavenge; he feasts
On the corpses of beasts.
This wild dude sees no need to keep lean!

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
So your s's resound off the wall
And your p's, plainly put, just appall?
Every breath can be heard?
You'll give up?  That's absurd.
Sing across mike—no hisses at all.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It's the battle arenas he's snubbed
And society's elbows he's rubbed.
He's a Buckingham lug
Who likes cutting the rug.
Thus the carpet knight aptly is dubbed.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"What's a dragon fish?" "Two tales unfold:
One's in tropical waters, extolled
For its form" —thus Beck reckoned.
"Antarctic, the second,
Is specially suited for cold."

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
When he gave her a single red rose
And she suddenly, wordlessly, froze,
Blind Freddy could tell
That the outcome would smell.
Even blokes with bad eyes have a nose.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Acrolectal, as you're a Jamaican
And speak creole for real, and not fakin',
Means your speech is quite near
Plain old English. I hear
A faint accent, unless I'm  mistaken.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Aban numbers will not have an a
When they're written in English this way:
Twenty-five, sixty-seven,
Four million eleven,
And more. What's their use? Who's to say?

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Round 1 is three minutes of chess.
In Round 2, boxing skills will impress.
Back and forth, brains and brawn—
A left hook, a lost pawn—
This is chess boxing. Difficult? YES!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Read your Bible; you'll find it will say
That Delilah led Samson astray.
He was fearless and strong
While his hair remained long;
Then a haircut took power away.

limerick_list.author: jojo
limerick_list.text:
"Oh, Salvadore, dahling! My Kewpie!
I'm ready and eager for whoopie.
All the clocks have struck one.
Come to bed—let's have fun."
"Not tonight, dear—I'm tired and droopy".

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
"To glaciate" can mean "to freeze,"
But it also can mean that the trees,
And the valleys and streets
Become buried in sheets
Of dense ice. I sure hope you have skis!

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
I grab bothersome things by the throat,
Slash and slice, then triumphantly gloat.
You think I'm a predator?
No, I'm an editor,
Pouncing on limericks you wrote.

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
When you're trolling for carp, don't complain
If the fish are not biting. Refrain
From all carping and whining;
The day's bright and shining.
Carpe diem — break out the champagne.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
A footballer based in Nairobi
Found the ground isn't flat and must so be
Just part of a sphere
And concluded from here
That our planet is ball-shaped: it's globy.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's a semi-soft goat cheese Cape Vessy
And a semi-hard type called Cap Cressy.
Careful! Do not confuse
Which is which, whose is whose,
Or your cheesy display could get messy.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
If I learn how to chirrup like birds
Or to moo like the cattle in herds,
Then my tale I will tell,
And communicate well
As I'm now at a loss  …  for words.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
The college may send me a letter
Of acceptance, and that would be better
Than rejection by far.
For the latter would mar
My ace record — I'm such a go-getter.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
At a hundred degrees water turns,
But its steam can cause third-degree burns.
At zero it freezes,
But frostbite displeases.
These are centigrade-measured concerns.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
If you want to see air pressure traffic
You should visit a lab barographic.
They record highs and lows
And see how it all goes—
Weather fiendish or wholly seraphic?

limerick_list.author: equinox
limerick_list.text:
A tragedy's wholly cathartical
If it purges your feelings, no particle
Of emotion retained,
Aristotle explained
In Poetics, his seminal article.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Today the verb barnstorm denotes
How a candidate hustles for votes.
In a multi-state tour,
Every town is a blur
Of kissed babies, long speeches, sore throats.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
Speak clearly and say what you mean.
Atween means the same as between.
But a tween—as a rule—
Is a child, now in school,
On the way to be coming a teen.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
'Twas an old aldern bowl, round and wide,
With fresh garlics and onions applied.
Its silvery wood
Looked especially good
With a heap of green salad inside.

limerick_list.author: jsolomon
limerick_list.text:
In pursuit of the boldest of gear,
To further her dancing career,
The exotic young lass
With a penchant for brass
Found a brazer to braze her brassiere.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
These allomerous crystals, you dope,
All look beautiful under the 'scope,
Although some compositions
May vary. My mission's:
Make chemistry clearer (I hope).

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
Dearest Daughter, I grieve that we've had
An unfortunate row gone so bad.
My dearly won dust-up
Caused our family to bust up.
Come home, please.  Sincerely, your dad.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
When finishing up at the chapel,
Michaelangelo surely did grapple
With one last detail,
Without which he'd fail:
Pertaining to Eve and the apple.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
Graphs and numbers may fill you with wrath,
But there's help to be had; there's a path:
Use a graph paper grid.
Lines will help you get rid
Of the chaos suffusing your math.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Don't get drunk on the isle of Capri.
It's a beautiful island to see,
But Italians are lovers;
Too late one discovers
A case of acute STD.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
She appears to me often in dreams.
"Which way to Kentucky?" she screams.
It is clear she's a most
Overstrung sort of ghost,
And not good with directions, it seems.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
The physicist H. A. H. Boot
Had a mind both intense and astute.
In research he impressed
So that radar progressed
By the cavity magnetron route.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Bacterioscopy: one of the terms
For the study of microbes and germs.
Through the lenses I peer;
I prefer this career
To a job giving haircuts and perms.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
At a sleazy cafe known as Abbott's,
Drinking greyhounds is one of my habits.
Made with grapefruit juice, gin,
Over ice—with a grin,
I'm soon chasing mechanical rabbits.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Descriptivism says that my morals
(Value judgements) should never cause quarrels.
My deep motivation
Defies demonstration;
I rest on inscrutable laurels.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
There's an odd, indefinable charm
To my boom truck's extendable arm.
Heavy goods still need crating?
She's my lady in weighting.
Then she'll hoist any burden—no harm.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
The Knights Templar of Malta, accused
Of dark heresies, simply refused
To admit that they prayed
To Baphomet, or strayed
From the creed that the Mother Church used.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
A sea nettle, taking a whack
At some words in Cnidaria's FAQ,
Said, "Abapical's south
Of my apex (see mouth),
While abactinal's up on my back."

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
On a cruise ship, I met, near the pool,
A Cilician.  So, keeping my cool,
I inquired, "You're a Turk?"
He replied, with a smirk,
"But from Tarsus and not Istanbul."

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
A cow nibbles nettles herbivorously.
A bear gobbles cattle carnivorously.
A babe in a cot'll
Drink milk from a bottle.
A man eats the lottle—omnivorously.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
It's apparent, so obvious and true—
Like these apples are green, my eyes blue.
Stop saying it—cease,
I'm not really obese!
Now just dish me some more of that stew!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Think of down feathers,  fleecy and fluffy.
Stuff your pillow—they're flossy and puffy.
Fill your parka or vest;
You'll find eiderdown best,
Not like flight feathers—rough, coarse and scruffy.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
My cards tonight aren't that grand,
But they're falling the way that I planned.
This master just hasta
Fill one more canasta
To score the most points on this hand.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
There once was a warrior, Cochise,
An Apache, who vowed he'd not cease
From defending his land
In the West. Though his band
Fought for years, still Cochise died in peace.

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
It's another day, ho-hum, but — Hey!
I haven't had ice cream today.
The anticipation,
A pleasant sensation,
Is meltingly marvelous, Yay!

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
I'd rather not rudely impose,
But I can't help but state that your nose
Is not Roman or elfinoid.
It's definitely delphinoid,
Being bottle-shaped.  (Also, it glows.)

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
The neophyte duellist made
His challenge once anchor was weighed.
But the fool was soon skewered:
My ship slewed to leeward
(Fell off) and he fell — on my blade.

limerick_list.author: Harris Risman
limerick_list.text:
I'm "bipolar," or so says my shrink.
"Take your meds, and do not make a stink.
If you start acting manic,
Some people will panic;
They might throw your ass in the clink."

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
There once was a man named Cousteau,
Who explained, "In the oceans below,
Deep-sea divers like me
Can be seen on TV,
As we swim with the stars of the show."

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Asymptotic solutions are fine.
Each appears as a single straight line
On the plot of your function;
But two in conjunction
Will make a good tool for design.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
His tennis career badly swerved
When, by injury weakened (enerved),
Herbie's famous fast serve
Lost its near-perfect curve—
Was it karma poor Herbie deserved?

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Spud's pugnaciously spoiling to fight,
Acting sassily crassly despite
Looking more like a fool
Than a dude who's real cool.
Chippy combativeness is his blight.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
To bash your wife's wrong, yes? Er, no,
According at least to James Vaux.
To wit, his reflection:
"It's just for correction..."
(Vaux's blowen knows Vaux's pose is faux).

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Though smoked chèvre's attached to its name,
There's no smoking involved. What's their game?
It's made with paprika.
On pork chops? Eureka!
"What a treat!" the UKers proclaim.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"You don't bartender here, serving rounds.
That's a term just as wrong as it sounds.
You tend bar, Jack!" (It's clear
This drunk schoolteacher here
Is opposed to the verbing of nouns.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
They say hip-hop is big with the young.
That's a group I'm no longer among.
I'm a fan of the Kinks
And the Turtles. Methinks
This millennium's music is dung!

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
A cryer's a weeper (boo hoo),
Or a trained female falcon (true, too);
And a guy who's a buyer
Might buy from a cryer:
Squawker, hawk and a hawker. Hooroo!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The scarecrow is learning to feign
Having whatcha-ma-callit . . . a brain.
Now he's running for prez,
Or at least, 'til he says
Something heartless, ascared, or inane.

limerick_list.author: John Weigel
limerick_list.text:
I am green at this limerick craft:
When I write my poor rhythm goes daft.
Through revisions galore,
Amateurishness, or
Pure ineptitude, clabbers each draft.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Robert Jones, twenty bucks, 1 July,
Then ten more on the fifth from McFly."
The name that exists
For who-pays-what-when lists?
Aging schedules, but don't ask me why.

limerick_list.author: GeneralE
limerick_list.text:
All the airplay you get will add up:
Soon the royalties top up your cup.
Count the times your song's played
And make sure you get paid;
Pay your "dues" and they'll see that you sup.

limerick_list.author: Nathan Howe
limerick_list.text:
When I needed a cure for my houndlessness,
I gave an old Sheltie her poundlessness.
I can let her roam free;
She won't jump up, you see,
So her boundlessness comes of her boundlessness.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
My advice — my astute commonition —
Results from my sharp intuition.
Your false commination
(Your sham derogation)
Sounds stupid in juxtaposition.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Your fender has just been impacted,
A result of the way that you've acted:
You're a motorist prone
To be using a phone,
Inattentive and driving distracted!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A knight who was spoiling to kill a
Sworn enemy (with a scintilla
Of sense) often wore
Metal besagues, for
They protected his joints and axilla.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Here's the homework assigned to you, Billy: add
To your reading, the book Homer's Iliad."
Billy looked at the text
And was truly perplexed.
What's the number of pages? A chiliad!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I've exceptional talent within,
And my handwriting's neat as a pin,
But each morning and night
When I sit down to write,
I just never know where to begin.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Though the elm, a deciduous tree,
Is as English as English can be,
It succumbs to disease —
Called Dutch Elm, if you please:
A sad fall for the tall green grandee.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
The deurbanization I've seen
Means the city is gone. Now it's green.
This was asphalt and bricks;
Now I live in the sticks.
I miss plumbing; this hole's my latrine.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
As a kid, I was scared through and through
By a ghost who was haunting our flue.
Now I'm older—but could,
When I'm adding some wood
To the fire, get spooked. Déjà boo!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
If only he'd done what I said —
Not light farts but light candles instead —
He'd be much better off, in
Fact not in this coffin.
Yes, he'd surely have come out ahead.

limerick_list.author: Chavi Beck
limerick_list.text:
There's a toddler I know (little girlie)
Whose hair is delightfully curly.
Bouncy ringlets like springs
Dance along as she sings,
Spins, and waltzes. (Her pink dress is twirly!)

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
BYU men must ask for permission
To grow beards.  A distinct admonition
In the honor code there
Disallows facial hair.
Notes from docs will exempt prohibition.

limerick_list.author: kavi
limerick_list.text:
If you'd like to hike mile after mile
In classically elegant style,
Just try on some socks
In a pattern that rocks —
The diamonds that form the argyle.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Antistrophe — let us repeat
Certain words as we finish. 'Tis mete
To complete every clause
With such phrases, because
As our ends meet, our finish is neat.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
It's in fantasyland you reside.
You imagine that gal by your side.
Sorry, bud.  In your dreams.
She won't go to extremes
And date dorks.  She's too cool for that ride.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The pilot was fearful about
Safety problems he noted throughout
His whole plane, but right now
It is airborne somehow,
Its airworthiness highly in doubt.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
An unfortunate man from Peru
Went dressed up as a bear to the zoo.
As he roamed thus attired,
All the keepers conspired
To entrap him — he's locked in Cage Two!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Though you're tough and grew up in a shtetl,
Seems you fear that a leech might unsettle
Your psyche. Afraid?
Use bdellometers made,
As a substitute leech, out of metal.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
So that hunger and danger will aller,
They appear, a grotesquely tense ballet.
For the good of the town,
They submit to the Crown:
Taut and tortured, The Burghers of Calais.

limerick_list.author: Snowy Owl
limerick_list.text:
Your axioms tell what you take
As the principles nothing can shake:
What your proofs presuppose
Before seeing what flows
From the logical waves in their wake.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
There's a Turk and a Cypriot fight,
And it's hard to say who's in the right;
For the name of the game
Is to alter the name
Of the sweet once called "lumps of delight."

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
I've anuria—no cause for glee.
What will ever become of poor me?
My underfilled bladder
Gets badder and badder,
Since my kidneys are not making pee.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
A new cook for the ranchers was got,
Since the last one's work wasn't so hot.
He could only cook stew,
And that tasted like glue,
So the old biscuit shooter they shot.

limerick_list.author: C. H. Carpenter
limerick_list.text:
The promotion of volumes for sale,
Like Dan Brown's new conspiracy tale,
Forms the bookselling trade,
Where vast fortunes are made
Just by retailing Christ's Holy Grail.

limerick_list.author: Meps Schulte
limerick_list.text:
The boardsailor ran down the beach,
Then checked both his luff and his leach.
He tested the wind,
And said, as he grinned,
"You can't catch me when I'm on a reach!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Help his brother drain gas? Tim abstains,
Since it's clear Ted's deficient in brains.
He'll exhaust all the gas
From the tank then, alas,
Strike a match to see how much remains.

limerick_list.author: JimCoates
limerick_list.text:
If you're injured or feeling quite sickly,
It can sometimes be dealt with quite quickly.
If your doc is a whiz,
Day surgery it is.
Your procedure is handled quite slickly.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
Pre-eclampsia seems pretty rough,
But eclampsia really is tough.
Your BP's so high
You'll have fits, and may die—
Isn't just giving birth bad enough?

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Just imagine the Roman god, Janus,
With two fronts and no back—and no anus.
So aproctous a god
Seems impractically odd:
What would so much redundancy gain us?

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
A disorder that dentists have named
As dental fluorosis is blamed
On fluoride ingestion
At levels they question.
Result? Changed appearance, they claimed.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Like the King when he sang "In the Ghetto",
And Gilda in Joe's Rigoletto,
To be more appealing,
Please do it with feeling —
Bring tears to their eyes, con affetto.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My friend Rita had asked that I meet 'er
At her brother's new bistro: Chez Peter.
When I groused that the meat
Was as hard as concrete,
Rita cried, "Gee, you're some picky eater!"

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Manufacturing processes vary;
Conforming to specs can be hairy.
But there are no enigmas:
Plot mean and three sigmas,
And for points outside limits, be wary.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan and Workshop
limerick_list.text:
There's a word that I learned today, cline,
That I'll try in this rhyme to define:
It's "a gradual change
Seen across any range,"
And not Patsy, whose songs were divine.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The word alcohol first meant a dry
Sort of powder to highlight the eye.
Just a pinch for each lid
Made them dark—oh, you kid!
(It would turn into booze by and by.)

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
My hanger-on houseguest said, "Dude,
Dispurveyance! You're fresh out of food."
Since spongers incite me,
I said to him, "Bite me,"
A comeback the creep misconstrued.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
When the blade of my mower, mein Gott,
Broke in half and attacked me, I shot
Straight inside, whining, "Jeez!
I've a wrecked ankle! Please — "
"Splendid shape," said my wife, "but so what?"

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
Said daughter to mother, "Oh, please.
All this talk of the birds and the bees?
Mom, you never would pass
My biology class,
For they never cross-fertilize. Jeez!"

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
You're trying to write every day
But you really have nothing to say.
To suit the occasion?
A simple erasion—
That's rub it all out; walk away.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
If you're excubitorium bound,
You will need to climb up from the ground.
It's a gallery. Where?
In a church. Public prayer
Would be offered all night there. Profound!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The fossil hounds digging around
For remains of old trees in the ground
Thought the Metasequoia
Extinct, but oh boy, a
Dawn redwood, in China, was found.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Boy, my teacher was vexed—she was steamin'!
"Chris, a demonym's use," she was screamin',
"Is to spotlight just where
You were born. Be aware
It does not mean 'the name of a demon'!"

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Is gangsta a sly affectation,
Disaffection's mutated creation?
Or do kids who all hang
On the street in a gang
Lack the basics of, er, education?

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
"Bosworth Field is where I will defend
My great realm," Richard cried, "I'll not bend!"
But soon he was forced
To concede, when unhorsed,
"I've a hunch that my reign's at an end."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
My life was on Easy Street, humming
Along.  Now this downfall is numbing.
I lost all my cash
In the stock market crash.
I find life in the slums unbecoming.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
When the holiday season approaches,
Our kitchen's infested with roaches,
'Cause where goodies are found
Is where roaches abound.
It's where every encroaching roach poaches.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Filled with custard, my doughnut," said Cher,
"Is a tasty delight." "Au contraire,"
Replied Sonny. "You're wrong.
Looking endwise it's long.
What you've got is a chocolate eclair."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Bruce's thesis abounds in abstruseness.
It has no major theme, and its looseness
Makes me sigh, "What's the use?"
I can find no excuse
For his rambling, unfocused diffuseness.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Lady hikers can get in a stew
When they know calls of nature are due.
It's just when to fall back
From the men in the pack
In their search for an improvised loo.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
In a chimney sweep contest, Bo Peep
Took first place with the aid of her sheep.
Also second, and third,
Fourth, and fifth place—my word!
It was clear she had scored a clean sweep.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
I'm a person who's really excited
By gadgets, and really farsighted.
I'll often pursue
All the things they can do,
With my gadgeteer's calling delighted.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"Those embattled guys must have been nude.
Dad, is that why he called this bridge rude?"
"No, damn sure they were right —
They were ready to fight.
And the bridge? Well, it's roughly built, crude."

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
Asymmetrical balance in art
Means the sides are uneven; one part
Has more visual weight.
The results, though, are great
If, aesthetically speaking, you're smart.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Creeping wintergreen grows where I dwell.
 It's an evergreen—minty as well.
 Both the grouse and the fawn
 To its berries are drawn
 By the slight scent of toothpaste they smell.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The caterer said, "It's in vogue—
From this fountain will wine disembogue,
As your guests fill their glasses."
But it drips as wine passes,
And it stains all their clothes. He's a rogue.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
'Cause of harsh puritanical views
Via blue laws, we're down with the blues.
I strongly object
To a Sabbath respect
That enforces a ban on all booze.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Asked a freshman of fellow frosh Josh:
"Do you know that new prof? Truly posh!
When I see her—my gosh—
She looks sweet as a nosh."
"What nonsense," thought Josh, and said: "Bosh!"

limerick_list.author: Julia
limerick_list.text:
When told to acquire common shares
To improve your financial affairs,
You just might be deterred
From both those and preferred
If you can't tell the bulls from the bears.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
It was probably far too ambitious
Of the doughtier long-ago fishes
To crawl from the seas
And walk among trees,
But the outcome was fairly propitious.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"I can hear him! He's here," whispered Ted.
And then Moe went, "Just aim for his head."
And then Tom went, "Who cares,"
As Doe came up the stairs,
"Where we shoot him as long as he's dead?"

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
My despisedness means that disgust
Fills the eyes that I'm seen with; I trust
People think that my style
Is distinctively vile,
Because under their breath I am cussed.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Wearing black hats, black caftans and pants,
The Chassidim got ready to dance.
They sang as they prayed,
And their whole bodies swayed
As they worked themselves into a trance.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
The declarer confessed with great class,
"Yes, I killed my bridge partner, alas.
While I'm sorry he died,
It was all justified:
I bid 'Two clubs.' And then 'Pass.' 'Pass.' 'Pass.'"

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
In the garden, this beautiful morn,
Epipetalous details adorn.
Look closely, come near:
See how stamens adhere
To the petals, delightfully borne.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Beg your pardon, please, Don Corleone.
Tommy Dorsey just called on the phone.
Says he cannot refuse
That last offer from youse.
Now, your donship, I'll leave you alone.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
She sucks up to the boss, see her fall
All over him — how she's the gall ...!
She cajoles, brings him tea,
Almost screams, "Look at me —
See, I'll just lick your boots while I crawl."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
So he paid the guy 5,000 bucks
And was promised a truck that's de luxe.
What he got was repainted,
And Chuck nearly fainted.
"That purple and green," he said, "sucks!"

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
After goring the man I adore,
The bull's horns bore his blood — gore galore.
They had pierced my love's chest
To the heart. I detest
Steak tartare, but it evens the score.

limerick_list.author: BobfromThirsk
limerick_list.text:
The Apple of Sodom looks sweet,
Oh so ripe! and so tempting! a treat!
But appearance deceives—
There's a puff; all it leaves
Is the skin and some threads, what a cheat!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Green members of Congress declare
We should care for our water and air:
We're befouling our Earth!
They point out, without mirth,
We have no other planets to spare.

limerick_list.author: Virge
limerick_list.text:
Election time comes, and I flee.
Now tell me, sir, why should this be?
No details can be told
With counting by Diebold:
Abroad, I can vote absentee.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
If rice isn't your cup of tea,
Throw some birdseed, and soon you will see
That some extra guests fly
To your wedding! Just try!
I know, 'cause it happened for me.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Was the slav's Glagolitic so kooky,
Acrophonically named from az, buki?
You should learn from your betters
When naming your letters:
What comes after "R" should be Spooky.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Joe scrambled aboard by pure stealth,
As he had more diseases than wealth.
If they knew of their stowaway,
The crew could but throw away
Their paper stamped clean bill of health.

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
Ah, Ramón! No-one warned him, poor boy:
Minnie Phelps thought of him as her toy.
He was young and impulsive;
His glands turned convulsive.
(These spasms filled Minnie with joy.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If you take a tuberculin test,
Cell immunity kicks in. Impressed?
It is cell-mediated,
And quite underrated,
But potent, my doctors suggest.

limerick_list.author: Lostock Hall
limerick_list.text:
Ensign Full, as he shook like a reed,
Felt his bladder acceding to need.
Clear across Mobile Bay,
Folks heard Farragut say:
"Damn the torpedoes!  Full's peed!"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Dialectics are used to arrange
The Hegelian process of change
Into stages—just three.
In the middle, we see
The antithesis—contrary, strange.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
A reader of Marx and Voltaire,
While doubtingly starting a prayer,
Said, with heavenly glance,
"I must look, Lord, askance—
Your existence is up in the air!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The Greeks thought the Persians barbaric,
Yet they surely admired the daric,
And were quick to purloin
This pure gold minted coin.
Now it's only a word, dictionaric!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
As to what it might take to compel
Cal to talk? Try a cold day in hell.
When she heard Coolidge died,
Dottie Parker replied
(So the story goes), "How could you tell?"

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Unique to the Chilean isles
Is Chiloe, well known for the styles
Of its churches of wood
(Many years they have stood),
And its houses on sturdy log piles.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Where's my landlord?  I wish I could phone her.
I'm not a complainer or moaner,
But she's never around
Though my plumbing's unsound.
Just my luck — she's an absentee owner.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
He's a Bolshie, my former friend Fred—
A card-carrying commie, a Red,
An admirer of Lenin.
You'd need antivenin
To clear these ideas from his head.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
With a ducktail, I'm here to report,
Just the hair on your cheeks is kept short.
As beards go, in the main,
It's remarkably plain,
A familiar and commonplace sort.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
With the grace of a bull, they all pass
Through the china shop, shattering glass.
With the breakage in heaps
The proprietor weeps,
While the grannies meander en masse.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I need new transportation quite badly,
But my bank account's hurting now, sadly.
There's a two-year-old Ford
For five hundred? I'm floored!
That's a price I would hand over gladly.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Since a plumber would bill for his trip,
And his knowledge, and wrenches that grip,
Do you wonder how come
I prefer Wrigley's gum
To repair leaky faucets that drip?

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Joe's oboe's tone's beau, virtuoso.
But no mojo — slow notes, flowing woe, so
Joe, whoa.  Oh, bro', stop.
No mo' blues.  Blow dat bop!
(I'm so over morose doloroso.)

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
When experts say wine is amusing,
It's a compliment.  Ain't that confusing?
Why laugh at a wine
If you think that it's fine?
Methinks they do far too much boozing.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
Rumors say specter dust settles grossly.
It's a haunting or chill, one feels mostly.
Thus at night, 'neath a moon —
The soft call of a loon —
It's a scene many deem sort of ghostly.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Bad actors we see on the screen
Rate as awful.  Their talent is lean,
But they're harmless.  Not so
For bad actors who go
Around acting like tyrants.  They're mean!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Some people don't grow very tall.
With de Lange's, the child remains small.
Brows are thick, hairline's low,
And his learning is slow—
This sad syndrome's not pleasant at all.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
Using father if one means the mother,
Or uncle in lieu of a brother,
Are tricks metaphoric.
They're all allegoric:
One image in place of another.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
A dye for the eyelids is what
Calliblephary was, and I've got
Some indelible yellow
(I'm that sort of fellow)
And lipstick to match — Man! I'm hot!

limerick_list.author: Carol O
limerick_list.text:
Spaghetti sauce, bubbling and hot,
Commands me to come to the pot,
Where the scent of sweet basil
So tempts my sense nasal
That I think I will dine on the spot.

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
The archer who loved life agrarian
Was considering settings riparian,
For placing a farm
By a river with charm
Seemed better for courting Maid Marian.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
In the throes of an asthma attack,
When O2 is the thing that you lack,
With no bronchodilator,
It's "Dude, see you later!"
Or not—you might not make it back.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
From her balcony, Juliet cried:
"How I wish for a man by my side!"
"Soft, what light yonder breaks?
'Tis my love that awakes
In my heart that which can't be denied."

limerick_list.author: splendiferous
limerick_list.text:
Her beauty, 'tis said, is a sight.
She's surely an angel of light.
Her assets bodacious,
Divinely capacious,
Are 44Ds of delight.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
When you say, "There's no God", that's profane,
And your adverts give cause to complain.
We believe you should prove
What you state, or remove
All those atheist words we disdain.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The neurologist Dr. Charcot
Lived in Paris, a long time ago.
He studied neurosis
By using hypnosis,
Upending the old status quo.

limerick_list.author: Quickbeam
limerick_list.text:
The antepenultimate word
Of this limerick isn't absurd,
Or even befriend
(Though that's nearer the end):
It's just it's—counting back, it's the third.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
"I'm all 'oarse, doc; me cough's a real rasper. It's
Bloody 'orrible — can't smoke me gasper. It's
'Ot as 'ell, is me 'ead."
Having heard what he said,
I advised him to take a few aspirates.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My husband's a first-rate provider,
Strong as steel, and as soft as an eider.
But it terrified me
When I found him to be
Arachnophagous, eating a spider!

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
Did you know there are two things named aureus?
Staphylococcus, the germ. Quite notorious.
And a gold coin from Rome
(If you have one at home,
You are probably feeling, like, glorious).

limerick_list.author: Rose Nunez
limerick_list.text:
This critic's of minor repute;
His empathy's much too acute:
The awful soprano
Who shrieked through "È strano!"
He called "just minutely argute."

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Caveman Dana agreed that his maul
Might be useful in quelling a brawl.
Though his words sounded mordant,
His view was concordant
With mine—namely, one size fits all.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Caterina's got plenty o' nuttin',
'Cept a kitty that's cute as a button —
Very cute, like the lamb
She'd adored and named Sam
But was forced to convert into mutton.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
Last night's supper? My count is fifteen:
The grandee (who I'm told's Nazarene),
His best buds (one's a traitor),
And this hot looking waiter,
Plus some guy who was painting the scene.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
I thought I could hear, close behind,
Furtive footsteps — the shuffling kind.
"Who'd follow me, coldly?"
I told myself, boldly,
But shivered, and quickly ran blind.

limerick_list.author: Bato
limerick_list.text:
I'll attempt to explain my position
After many long hours of revision;
I try to keep writing,
But line 5 keeps fighting
To spoil my chance with this mission.

limerick_list.author: kengrey
limerick_list.text:
A bra is a vessel of sorts
That occupies men's waking thoughts
On whether it's just
To measure one's bust
In imperial gallons or quarts.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I'm an expert at two kinds of acronym:
The reverse-engineered, called a bacronym,
And the kind that is nested —
Lord help us, infested! —
With acronyms. That's  called a macronym.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's a hooker I met in Quebec
Who had foolishly taken my check.
When it bounced, she said, "Hey!
You treat ladies this way?
If I catch you, I'll break your damn neck!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
You insist Donald Trump is a saint.
You sat down on a bench marked "Wet Paint".
You confuse pray and prey,
And spell cat with a k,
So let's face it, a genius you ain't.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
DoggoLingo, the experts maintain,
Is an internet language. Explain!
Well I think they're naïve
Who would have us believe
It reflects a dog's thoughts in its brain.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
I'll tell you with all due sincerity,
My fingers are lacking dexterity.
My skills alphabetic
Are truly pathetic.
At the keyboard, I type with temerity.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle and turnip
limerick_list.text:
What's a beemaster know about? Drones.
And a bellmaster? Carillon tones.
A brewmaster? Ales.
And a bandmaster? Scales.
You've bemastered those subjects! (She groans.)

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
To search for a meal on a shore,
A sandpiper finds, is no bore.
Just to beachcomb is bliss;
To be elsewhere, remiss —
And has seldom occurred heretofore.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
At college, when me and my buddies
(In our dorm's agricultural studies)
Tried to grow Mary Jane,
We were caught once again
By the dean and the cops (fuddy-duddies!).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My computer now handles my money.
I'm banking on line, and it's funny
That my login's the same
As a boxing champ's name.
What's my cryptonym? Call me Gene Tunney!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
I beg your forgiveness, my dear;
I've got news you would rather not hear:
Your skirt's caught in your knickers
(Which explains all the snickers).
From where I sit, your assets are clear.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
After pinching the boss, I was canned;
It was done by my alien hand!
Man, it's out of control,
And it's taking its toll—
These damned aliens ought to be banned.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
The dray horses used to get stuck
Hauling all of our stuff through the muck,
And echoing still
Are their whinnies of thrill
From the day we invented the truck.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This reporter's a dumb, mixed-up scribbler.
Try to edit his work? He's a quibbler.
When he covered the sport
On a basketball court,
He wrote: "Gibbs needs a bib; he's a dribbler!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Says my grandmother, "Nobody fools
With my jewelry. Those are the rules.
They've been ours," she explains,
"Since the Sioux ruled the plains."
Still we snicker at family jewels.

limerick_list.author: nevadaace and Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
He'll cursorily glance in her bag
And hope it holds big-ticket swag.
She's not really his type
For there's nothing to swipe,
Just used tissues, old mints, and a rag!

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
The edge of the cliff wears away
Through corrasion, since friction's in play.
Winds keep scouring the ground
With the sand that is found
In this desert and has the last say.

limerick_list.author: David R. Litwin
limerick_list.text:
The grand symphony chorus's sounds
Are quite consonous, unlike my hounds,
As they bay at the moon.
I do wish they could croon
Like that tenor, whose full voice astounds.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
"Will you look at the money we've spent!
It's an eye-watering sixty per cent
More than for the same quarter
Last year. Think we oughta
Now tighten our belts," I lament.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It appears that, for good or for bad,
He's the spit, not the image of Dad—
Who's a redhead, and proud
Of his counter, this loud
Little dribble-faced, towheaded tad.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
There was once a young lady named Bess
Who was constantly prone to digress.
When her truelove proposed,
Both his eyes were long closed
By the time she concluded with "Yes."

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
Christmas shearwater's this seabird's name.
Being shy, it has not garnered fame.
In Hawaii it's best
Found on isles northwest.
Males and females, in looks, are the same.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
On an architect's desk, one may see
A few technical sketches (croquis):
Maybe chic Arts and Crafts,
And although just rough drafts,
They're remotely backed-up on CD.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Dopart
limerick_list.text:
A blizzard down East is, like, so wind,
Wicked cold, you get freakin, like, snow-in'd.
But here in DC,
Switch on the TV,
Ten flakes . . .  and whoa! Towels are throw-in'd!

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Ethiopia hosts a soiree,
So an African journey's in play.
When you come, wear a skirt;
Eat a desert dessert.
Abyssinia soon now, okay?

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
This butterfly carving, to scale,
Is quite sturdy although it looks frail.
While this tiny conceit
Is an eye-candy treat,
It's a keeper, and not made for sale.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan Caws-Elwitt
limerick_list.text:
If you wear suspenders, by chance,
To hold up your trousers {or pants},
You needn't pull faces
To hear them called braces.
It's usage from Britain {near France}.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
There was an old dandy, named Andy,
Who found a small cask of French brandy.
Since only strong drink
Made him feel in the pink,
The cognac came in rather handy.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Sue's glum face isn't permanent, luckily.
For the most part, life treats her just duckily.
Then her countenance shows
That she's happy. She glows,
And her voice is decidedly chuckily.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
If you're quiet, immobile, and still,
And you cannot be moved, if you will,
Then you're actionless, so
Even friends may not know
If you're dead or just over-the-hill.

limerick_list.author: GaZoom
limerick_list.text:
Beefy Bob bought a dinghy: a boat
Using oars or a sail to promote
A safe course close to shore.
But a bailout's in store—
It's too dinky to keep Bob afloat.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Our approximate time of arrival
At Howard the Duck: The Revival?
A bit after eight.
Every minute we're late
Increases our chance of survival.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
What is making Doug nuts? Ugly bugs
That are snuggling beneath all his rugs.
Neither cuddly nor huggy,
They drive Dougie buggy —
Evoking from him yuks! and ughs!

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Coal is black as fresh snowfall is white.
Lead is heavy as helium's light.
So you're still looking for
One contrarium more?
New moon's dim as our sun star is bright.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"My case history reads like a novel.
I was raised in a broken-down hovel,
Made a fortune on stocks—
Now my life's on the rocks!
Can you save me?" I said, "Please don't grovel."

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
Being atherogenic in diet,
I cannot advise that you try it,
For the fat I consume
Takes up far too much room
In my blood vessels—I can't deny it.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Important affairs, when commercial
Or public, may be controversial.
Just the same may be true
Of a love affair, too,
So the married would best stay inertial.

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
I feel dimwitted most of the time,
'Cause I can't get my limericks to rhyme.
I've got words by the liter,
I'm good with the meter,
But dumb when I reach the last l.....

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
If you're planning to swim in the sea,
It's important to stay close to me,
But, especially important,
You know that you oughtn't
To swim where the sharks eat their tea.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Obsessive-compulsives, untreated,
Have ritual actions repeated.
Behavior that drastic
Is called anancastic,
And indicates problems, deep-seated.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Here's a bottomry bond; when you sign,
Fill your holds with what's precious and fine.
If your argosy's lost,
Then I'll swallow the cost.
Don't repay, and your vessel is mine.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Your writing's so bad, you're a jinx.
Don't you care what your readership thinks?
It is so beyond execrable,
Calling it drecksecrable
Sort of conveys how it stinks.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
An Ivy League brewer of tea
Made some ginseng, and gave it to me.
Araliaceous, loquacious,
And very flirtatious,
We chatted 'til well after three.

limerick_list.author: Beverley Sharp
limerick_list.text:
I'm abatic (unable to walk).
I try, but my muscles just balk.
Don't call me a cripple;
I'm dead drunk on Ripple—
Amazing I even can talk!

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
From the trinkets you've sent to embellish her
It is perfectly clear how you relish her—
But a wedding is out:
The credentials you tout
As a cherisher couldn't be hellisher.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
A good counsellor sifts through the lies
Told by couples at pains to disguise
The true facts, to select
What appears to affect
All the whos, and their whats, and their whys.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Who's the debonair Fred, famed for flair,
Whose game with his name forms a pair?
Here's a clue: the word dancers
Meant "stairs". Yes, the answer's
That twinkletoes star, Fred Astaire!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I'm pure evil; I'm bad to the bone.
Unrepentant, I never atone
For my sins.  Gotta say,
Many gals love the way
That I roll.  Thus, I'm never alone.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Though they're both pronounced COE-duh-suhl, these
Are as different as pork is from peas.
One is tacked to your will
When your kin make you ill;
One's a body with geek expertise.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Bioscientists study our lives.
Anthropologists count up our wives.
Sociologists know
How relationships go—
Yet my doc can't explain why I've hives!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
In Afghanistan lawmakers cobble
New laws as their state starts to wobble.
Will the Taliban loom
And project future gloom?
In old Kabul live fears that can hobble.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Fuzz  arrested me (call it "a rest"),
Stopped my heists (so-called  petty-crime fest).
When I ripped off some more,
Got re-busted (a bore!).
I've been pegged "Number One Repeat Pest".

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Kate's son Frank was a bathroom attendant.
Frank's son Donald on Dad was dependent.
Donald's daughter Marie
Had a son she named Lee
With a daughter who's not Kate's descendent.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Since his wound from the spear is severe,
They will cauterize, meaning to sear
With an iron so hot
It can make the blood clot,
But I fear it's a pain in the rear.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Glans penis is not owned by Glans.
It's the end cap of what is a man's
Most beloved male part,
Which is not his male heart.
My own bell-end has bevies of fans.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
While rickets can make your bones weak
And pellagra discolor your cheek,
Acute beriberi
Can make you sick, very —
Of avitaminosis I speak.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Women headed to market or church,
None let winds leave their locks in a lurch.
Nae!  The sight to be seen
In downtown Aberdeen
Was a well-knotted kerchief, a curch.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
My blood vessels — I can't content 'em.
The crap that I eat likely bent 'em.
The doc found a spot —
A gelatinous clot —
In medicalese: crassamentum.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
An announcer at Paddington Station,
Giving news of a track alteration,
Chose that moment to say,
"Did I mention I'm gay?"
(Which was, frankly, too much information.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Here's a reader from Boston who writes:
"When I travel the South I have fights
With the lunkheads down there
Who appear not to care
That it's wrong to say 'cut out the lights'!

(Signed) Correct Northerner"

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
So this atom thing looks like a ball—
Am I right?—but incredibly small?
And this probe thing can see
What it's like?  In 3D?!
But, uh ... what if it ain't there at all?

limerick_list.author: Kuranui
limerick_list.text:
A dolphin (a mammal cetaceous)
Finds the ocean, his home, very spacious.
While surfing the sea,
He has fish for his tea
And leaps from the waves—quite audacious!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A birdcall's the song of a bird,
Or an amateur act by a nerd,
Doing bird imitations
In search of ovations
That seldom, if ever, are heard.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Although life in this pond is divine,"
A young catfish was heard to opine,
"Every day without fail,
I'm receiving no mail.
